HEADLINE: The Extraordinary Who Lived Among Us

BYLINE: By DICK AHLES

 BODY:
IT is impossible to read the following remembrances of some of the Connecticut residents who died this year and not feel regret. It's not just the sadness over the death of truly extraordinary people, but that they lived such rich lives out of the view of so many of us. 
 Who wouldn't have loved to have sat down with Alix and Pierre Deguise to hear their tales of the French Resistance and going ashore at Normandy with Free French forces? Or to have danced to the music of Al Gentile or flown with the aviation pioneer Mary Goodrich Jenson, who learned to fly the year Charles A. Lindbergh landed in Paris? Or to have given a standing ovation to Patricia Kingsley Ritter, who spent a lifetime working for civil rights? 
 These were lives not to be missed. Here, briefly, are rememberances of a few written by Dick Ahles.

Fighting for France, but Teaching Here
 Alix and Pierre Deguise met and married after serving in separate French military organizations during World War II. Pierre Deguise was a member of the French Resistance and Ms. Deguise was with the Free French forces.
 Ms. Deguise was born in Paris and Mr. Deguise in Burgundy in eastern France. He was educated at the University of Lyon and the Sorbonne before the war and joined the French Army in 1938. After France's defeat, he became a member of the underground Resistance movement, was imprisoned, escaped and rejoined the Resistance.
 Ms. Deguise, who was Jewish, escaped from occupied Europe and came to New York when she was 15 with her mother and brother. After studying at the Lycee Francais of New York, she left Smith College at 18 to join Charles de Gaulle's forces in London. She reached Normandy three weeks after the invasion and was involved in providing relief to the residents of Caen, Boulogne, and Calais. She later worked with the survivors of concentration camps, including Bergen-Belsen, where many of her relatives had died.
 She resumed her education at the University of Aix en Provence and the University of Lausanne and married Mr. Deguise in Monaco in 1948. 
 They came to the United States in 1951 when Mr. Deguise joined the faculty of Wellesley College. In 1958, they moved to Connecticut College where Ms. Deguise taught French literature and civilization and Mr. Deguise was chairman of the French and Italian departments. They lived in Niantic.
 On July 29, Ms. Deguise, suffering from a blood clot on her lungs, was taken to Lawrence and Memorial Hospital in New London. In the emergency room, Mr. Deguise fell, broke his hip and also developed what proved to be a fatal blood clot on his lungs. Four hours after his death, Ms. Deguise also died.
 Ms. Deguise was 79 and Mr. Deguise was 88.

The First 'Girl Pilot'
 When the Hindenberg flew over Hartford in 1936, Mary Goodrich Jenson was the only woman on board.
 Ms. Jenson, then Mary Goodrich, was The Hartford Courant's first aviation editor as well as the first Connecticut woman to hold a pilot's license, having learned to fly in 1927 at age 20. 
 Mary Goodrich wrote for the newspaper while taking flying lessons at Brainard Field in Hartford and was billed by The Courant as its ''girl pilot.'' 
 In 1929, she became a member of Amelia Earhart's Ninety Nines, an international organization of female flyers. She was a director of the Betsy Ross Corps, a group of female pilots who assisted in national defense, and she was active in the Women Flyers of America, started in 1940 to free male pilots for military service by flying from factories to air fields and transporting supplies.
 She lived most of her life in Wethersfield, where she served on the Board of Education, Republican Town Committee and Council of Social Agencies of Greater Hartford.
 In 2000, she was inducted into the Connecticut Women's Hall of Fame in recognition of her aviation pioneering.
 Ms. Jenson died at Hartford Hospital on Jan. 4. She was 96.

Titan of the Big Bands
 They called Al Gentile the ''Titan of the Big Bands'' during the nearly seven decades he led dance bands in Connecticut and throughout the northeast.
 Mr. Gentile was born and raised in New Britain and began his musical career at New Britain Senior High School when he founded and led the school's pep band. He lived in New Britain for most of his life.
 After high school, Mr. Gentile organized the band Ten Melodeons until it expanded to 15 musicians and two vocalists. The band, renamed the Al Gentile Orchestra, performed throughout New England and along the Eastern Seaboard from the 1930's to 2000. 
 For many years, there were a number of Al Gentile Orchestras appearing in the region. ''He kept a lot of musicians working,'' said Ed Sarisley of Enfield, a former drummer with an Al Gentile Orchestra. 
 When he wasn't leading his dance band, Mr. Gentile worked as an agent, producer and booker of entertainment acts.
 A lifelong member of the American Federation of Musicians, Mr. Gentile served the musicians' union in several positions. Members of the union waived their fees when he performed a farewell concert in New Britain High School, where his career began, in 2000.
 Mr. Gentile died Feb. 18. He was 88.

A Woman's Voice in Barkhamsted
 Carmella Lattizori's election as the first selectwoman of Barkhamsted in 1985 ended what The Hartford Courant called, ''about 200 years of Republican males serving in that office.'' She would serve for 11 years and was a leader of the community and an advocate for its citizens for decades.
 Ms. Lattizori had unsuccessfully run for first selectwoman in two previous elections and after retiring as first selectwoman, she continued to serve on the board of selectmen until 1999 and was also Barkhamsted's Democratic registrar of voters and a member of other town boards. 
 Ms. Lattizori was co-founder of the Valley Thrift Shop in New Hartford and the Susan B. Anthony Project for battered women in Torrington. As first selectwoman, she also helped to organize the bipartisan Litchfield Hills Council of Elected Officials. During her years on the board of selectmen, she played a leading role in two major community projects, the construction of a new town hall and renovations of the elementary school.
 Ms. Lattizori died at St. Francis Hospital in Hartford July 7. She was 70. Her husband, Francis, will help dedicate a flag pole in her memory on the grounds of the Barkhamsted Town Hall following the town's Independence Day parade next year.

'A Good, Vibrant Newsroom'
 E. Bartlett Barnes, the publisher of The Bristol Press from 1956 to 1985, was one of the last proprietors of independent, family-owned newspapers that once thrived in many Connecticut small towns.
 Donald Selena, who worked with Mr. Barnes at The Press for 43 years, said Mr. Barnes ''wanted to make enough money to support a good, vibrant newsroom.'' He cared about advertising, circulation and other areas of the newspaper, but his main purpose as a publisher was to be sure he had a good newsroom, Mr. Selena said.
 Mr. Barnes grew up in Bristol, graduated from Yale in 1929 and worked as a reporter and advertising salesman at The Stamford Advocate for eight years before joining the family's newspaper in 1937. During his 48 years at The Press, Mr. Barnes was ''almost synonymous with the town,'' said Thomas D. Kennedy III, president of Bristol Hospital. ''Every place you turned, every good deed that was done, he was part of it.''
 At various times, Mr. Barnes headed the Bristol Board of Education, the Library Board, the Boys Club, the Barnes Nature Center and the town's Industrial Development Board. He was a founder of the town's American Clock and Watch Museum, the Environmental Learning Centers of Connecticut and the New England Carousel Museum. He was a founding member of the Bristol Yale Club in the 1950's and established a scholarship fund that has helped dozens of Bristol students attend Yale.
 ''What he wasn't involved in wasn't important,'' Mr. Selena said.
 Mr. Barnes and his older brother, Clarkson, succeeded their father as co-publishers of The Press in 1956, and Mr. Barnes became president and publisher when Clarkson Barnes retired in 1968. 
 Mr. Barnes was a strong supporter of the public's right to know and was part of a group of publishers and editors who began pushing for a state freedom of information law in the 1950's. The law was passed in 1975 and Mr. Barnes served as a member of the state's Freedom of Information Commission in the 1980's. He continued to attend meetings of the Connecticut Council on Freedom of Information well into his '90's.
 Although most of his career was on the business side of his newspaper, Mr. Barnes always felt his greatest achievement in journalism occurred during the great 1955 flood. He waded through waist high water from The Press, which had lost its telephone lines, to the Southern New England Telephone Company, where he called in his account of the flood damage in Bristol to the Associated Press in Boston. But, he always added ruefully, the Associated Press mistakenly put Mr. Barnes's brother's byline on the story. 
 Mr. Barnes died Feb. 9 in his home in Bristol. He was 96. 

A True Boy Scout
 Kenneth Gunsalus of Danielson joined the Boy Scouts when he was 13 and stayed for 75 years.
 As a scoutmaster, Mr. Gunsalus spent 45 summer vacations leading his troops to summer camp. He had one of his greatest experiences in scouting in 1935 when he met Lord Robert Baden-Powell , who founded the Boy Scouts in England. In 1939 and 1940, Mr. Gunsalus led troops of Boy Scouts who worked as tour guides at the New York World's Fair.
 Mr. Gunsalus received the Scouts' highest honor, the Silver Beaver, and many other awards. The Kenneth Gunsalus Good Citizen's Award is given in his honor each year to students from Putnam Elementary School and St. Mary's School.
 In World War II, Mr. Gunsalus was an infantryman in the Pacific and served in the Connecticut National Guard for 10 years. An electrician, Mr. Gunsalus worked for Connecticut Light and Power for 43 years, retiring as a service foreman in 1977.
 Mr. Gunsalus died May 4 in Danielson. He was 88.

Helping the Polish
 Edward Pawlowski assumed many leadership roles in Hartford's Polish community, and he was especially proud of helping Polish immigrants become American citizens.
 Many Poles fled Poland after a Communist government gained control following World War II and many settled in the Hartford Polish community. Mr. Pawlowski befriended many of them and sponsored more than 250 immigrants for the naturalization classes that were required for citizenship.
 As manager and president of Hartford's Polish National Home, a popular gathering place for Polish-Americans, he organized many of the annual Pulaski-Kosciuszko Day Parades and was active in the Polish Legion of America Veterans Post and the Pulaski Democratic Club.
 In order to help Poles still living in Poland learn something about America and its national pastime, he was a director of the Polish National Youth Baseball Program that helped introduce the game to Poland. 
 A Hartford native and lifetime member of SS. Cyril and Methodius Church, Mr. Pawlowski was a graduate of the city's Bulkeley High School and captain of its 1936 football team. He attended Providence College on a football scholarship before enlisting in the Army and serving in the Pacific during World War II, where he was wounded and awarded the Purple Heart.
 As a two-term member of the City Council in the 1950's and 60's, Mr. Pawlowski was an early advocate of a civic center for Hartford. He worked for the state for many years and retired in 1987 as a superintendent in the Department of Public Works.
 Mr. Pawlowski died Nov. 2 in Hartford's St. Francis Hospital. He was 87.

Housing and Civil Rights Advocate
 In 1936, when Patricia Kingsley was a 16-year-old college freshman, she organized one of the nation's first anti-discrimination sit-ins at a restaurant in Iowa.
 Patricia Kingsley Ritter would continue to be active in the civil rights movement throughout her life. With her husband, George Ritter, a Hartford lawyer and former city councilman and state legislator, she founded the Connecticut Housing Investment Fund, which has, since the 1960's, helped more than 70,000 families move into integrated housing in the Hartford area, according to the Ritter family.
 The family also recalls that Ms. Ritter's efforts to integrate housing were met with violence on several occasions, including an incident in 1963 when an East Hartford mob nearly overturned her car with her and her 7-year-old son inside. 
 Ms. Ritter's first civil rights project in Connecticut was as New England director of the Citizens Committee on Displaced Persons, which helped many people who had fled Europe after World War II resettle in the United States.
 In 1950, Ms. Ritter was appointed to the Connecticut Commission on Human Rights by Gov. Chester Bowles. She was the first woman to be named to that commission. President Jimmy Carter made her a director of the National Housing Partnership in 1979. 
 At about the same time, Ms. Ritter founded China in Connecticut and helped China rebuild its libraries and universities. She taught at colleges in China and received an honorary doctor of humane letters degree from Heilongjiang University in Harbin, China. She also received an honorary degree from Lawrence University in Wisconsin and the distinguished alumni achievement award from the University of Iowa.
 Ms. Ritter taught English and American literature at West Virginia University, Hillyer College, now part of the University of Hartford, and Hartford College for Women. She was the mother of a daughter and four sons, including Thomas Ritter, who followed his father into the Connecticut General Assembly and was speaker of the house.
 Ms. Ritter died Dec. 10 at Hartford Hospital. She was 84.

Try and Try Again
 Donald Jepsen ran for the state House of Representatives in 1970 and circulated a campaign flier calling for a commuter rail line between Hartford and its suburbs, harsher penalties for drug dealers, alternatives to low income housing projects and fiscally responsible state government. He lost.
 Eighteen years later, Mr. Jepsen ran for the state Senate and handed out the same document, saying the issues hadn't changed in 18 years. He also lost that race.
 Mr. Jepsen was the owner of the Built Rite Engine Exchange in Hartford and Windsor Locks until 1972 when he was appointed state unemployment compensation commissioner by then Gov. Thomas Meskill. He was reappointed by Gov. Ella Grasso and later served as an administrative law judge until he retired in 1988.
 He was an avid sailor, earning the ''N'' for navigator designation from the United States Power Squadrons. In 1994, Mr. Jepsen served on a small ship that traced Christopher Columbus' route from Spain to America.
 Mr. Jepsen died at his home in New London on Jan. 24. He was 71.

The First Lady of Avon
 They called Beatrice Murdock France ''the first lady of Avon'' and with good reason.
 A resident of Avon for 36 years, Bea Murdock, as she was known in the town, served on the Board of Selectmen for seven years, five of them as first selectwoman. She represented the town in the Connecticut House of Representatives during the 1980's, and in 1989 she was elected to the Town Council, which had replaced the selectman form of government. She was one of the founders of Avon Day, an annual community celebration.
 A lifelong Republican, Ms. France considered herself an ardent supporter of home rule. As a legislator, she co-sponsored the bill that created the statewide 911 emergency telephone network.
 Ms. France was also involved in many other Avon and Farmington Valley organizations. She was a soloist and choir director at the West Avon Congregational Church, president of the Avon Red Cross and a member of the Farmington Valley Association for the Retarded and Handicapped, and the Farmington Valley Visiting Nurses' Association, among others. 
 Ms. France was born and raised in Connecticut and graduated from Mount Holyoke College in 1954, the year she married James Murdock of Guilford. Two years after Mr. Murdock's death in 1986, she married Bud France of Avon. The couple moved to Cape Cod in 1994.
 Ms. France died in March at her home in Eastham, Mass. She was 71.

A Proponent of the Gifted
 William Vassar Sr.'s professional life was dedicated to helping gifted and talented students reach their educational potential. 
 Colleagues credit him with expanding gifted programs in Connecticut schools from four when he joined the Department of Education in 1966 to more than 140 today. Mr. Vassar was director of the Department of Education programs for gifted and talented children from 1966 to 1986 and later served as coordinator of gifted education at Central Connecticut State University. 
 From 1967 to 1970, he conducted a 50-state study for President Lyndon Johnson's White House Task Force on the Gifted and Talented. Over the years he published 72 articles on the subject. In 2002, he was named one of the 50 most influential people in the field by the National Association for Gifted and Talented Children. He was a past president and vice president of that organization.
 Mr. Vassar was also a sports enthusiast and worked for more than 30 years as a Division I college baseball umpire. He also umpired minor league baseball games and was a scout for the San Francisco Giants. After the baseball season ended, Mr. Vassar refereed college football.
 Mr. Vassar died in November in Hartford. He was 79.

Not Just Any Teacher, but the Best
 Fred Kort was studying law at the University of Vienna in 1938 when the Nazis came to power in Austria and expelled him along with other Jewish students.
 Mr. Kort immigrated to the United States, joined the United States Army in 1942 and returned to Europe as a member of the 11th Armored Division. He fought in the Battle of the Bulge in the winter of 1944 and ended his European tour of duty back in Vienna.
 After the war, Mr. Kort resumed his interrupted education at Northwestern University, receiving his bachelor's, master's and Ph.D. degrees in four years. Upon joining the political science faculty at the University of Connecticut in 1950, Mr. Kort predicted he would have a 40-year career there, according to his family. He retired from the university in 1990.
 Mr. Kort was admired as a researcher and teacher and the students named him the best teacher at the university in 1964. He was a pioneer in applying mathematical techniques and the computer to political science. As a fellow at the University of Chicago Law School in 1958 to 1959, he worked with the early Univac 1 computer. He enjoyed telling how the Univac had to be shut down on Tuesdays and Fridays to change the tubes. Later, he did considerable research on how biological determinants influence political behavior. 
 Mr. Kort died July 17 in Bloomfield. He was 85.

'The Egg Lady'
 Adaline Laughlin was a pewtersmith and glass artist, but she was best known as ''the Egg Lady'' for her skill at the art of pysanky, or Ukrainian Easter egg decorating.
 Ms. Laughlin was a Connecticut Yankee descended from 17th century settlers who founded Hartford, Wethersfield and Windsor, which is why she sometimes called her creations Scots-English-Irish-Ukrainian eggs. 
 Ms. Laughlin was living in Ridgefield in 1972 when a friend taught her how to apply dyes and beeswax to drained raw eggs to create Ukrainian eggs. For the next 32 years, she passed her skills on to many others and decorated eggs that were both traditional and of her own design. One of her eggs has been an ornament on the Christmas tree in the Connecticut governor's residence and since 2001, another has represented the state on the White House tree.
 For many years, Ms. Laughlin ran a workshop for school children at the Washington School in Manchester where she and her family lived in a home that was built by her great grandfather in 1842.
 Ms. Laughlin's work in pewter hollowware and glass jewelry has been exhibited and sold nationally. As president of the Society of Connecticut Craftsmen, she organized exhibitions and shows featuring Connecticut crafts at the Old State House in Hartford and at other historic sites in the state.
 Ms. Laughlin died Oct. 25 at St. Francis Hospital in Hartford. She was 67. 

Stalwart for the Schaghticoke
 Paulette Crone-Morange of Monroe was a leader of the Schaghticoke Tribal Nation in Kent and had an important role in the tribe's 25-year campaign to obtain federal recognition.
 As the tribe's administrator and historian, Ms. Crone-Morange poured over long forgotten historical records and tribal documents to obtain recognition from the federal Bureau of Indian Affairs. Recognition was denied in 2002, but the decision was reversed by the agency in January. The reversal is being appealed by the state Attorney General and the town of Kent, opponents of the tribe's plan to build a casino in Bridgeport or western Connecticut.
 Ms. Crone-Morange served at various times as secretary of the Tribal Council and vice chairwoman and project coordinator for the tribe's applications for federal recognition and grants. She was also chairwoman of the state's Indian Affairs Council.
 Ms. Crone-Morange died in Bridgeport on March 23 of an aneurysm. She was 60.

Madge, the Palmolive Manicurist
 Jan Miner was an actress on the Broadway stage, in radio and in films, but she was best known as Madge, the manicurist who soaked her clients' fingers in Palmolive liquid soap in a long running series of television commercials.
 Connecticut radio listeners first knew Ms. Miner as one of the members of the ensemble Guy Hedlund Players on WTIC in the 1930's and 1940's. The troupe also included the actors Michael O'Shea and Ed Begley.
 Ms. Miner was born in Boston and came to Hartford in 1941 to play host to two women's programs, ''A Woman's Day'' and ''Woman's Point of View,'' in addition to performing with the Hedlund troupe. She also wrote commercials for the now defunct, but once prominent Hartford businesses Sage Allen department store and Honiss's Oyster House. 
 On July 6, 1944, the station assigned Ms. Miner to accompany 16 school children and their teacher to the Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus, which was playing in a tent in Hartford's North End. In a 1991 interview with The Hartford Courant, she recalled leaving the performance early to prepare her broadcast. As she reached the street, the tent burst into flames. 
 The children WTIC had treated to the circus survived because one of them, a Boy Scout, used his pocket knife to slash the tent and his classmates and the teacher fled. The fire killed 169 people, including several women and children.
 After leaving WTIC, Ms. Miner was the leading lady in the network radio drama ''Boston Blackie.'' She made her Broadway debut in 1948 and appeared in many Broadway and off Broadway shows from the 1940's to the 1980's.
 But it was the Madge commercials that made Ms. Miner famous. She did the commercials in French, German, Italian and Danish and credited them with giving her the freedom to do the stage roles she preferred.
 Ms. Miner died Feb. 15 at a health care center in Bethel. She was 86.

Tuning In in the Classroom
 Eugene (Jack) Dahlby was a broadcaster and an educator who used his broadcasting skills in the classroom as a teacher of English, speech and acting.
 Mr. Dahlby's first broadcasting job was as a 21-year-old announcer at radio station WNAB in Bridgeport in 1941. He worked at the station until 1954, except for time spent as a fighter pilot in World War II. After the war, he remained in the Air Force Reserve and retired as a major.
 In 1955, Mr. Dahlby became a teacher, first at the Baker School in Darien for seven years and then at Darien High School, where he taught from 1962 to 1980. During that period, he continued to work in radio as a staff announcer at WSTC in Stamford.
 After retiring from the high school, he remained active in radio and television as a narrator and an actor in educational and industrial films and as a commercial spokesman. 
 Mr. Dahlby was a charter member and past president of the Darien Showcase Theater and appeared in many of its productions. 
 Mr. Dahlby died Dec. 3 in Clinton. He was 84. 

Adding a Window of Beauty
 Before she retired and moved to Unionville, Marion Foster lived for many years in the Charter Oak Terrace public housing development in Hartford.
 She tried to make Charter Oak Terrace a better place in which to live, and in 1969 the Hartford Housing Authority gave her its Good Citizenship Award for doing just that. 
 To her neighbors, Ms. Foster was known as ''the window box lady,'' a tribute to the window boxes of flowers she maintained at her apartment. She encouraged others to install the boxes to make the development more attractive. 
 She also founded an organization known as ''Give a Hand to a Boy,'' which sponsored educational trips and recreational activities for the boys in the neighborhood.
 Ms. Foster worked as a seamstress and raised a son and six daughters. She died April 30 at age 78.

The Best Dress, Always
 During the middle decades of the 20th century, Pratt Street in downtown Hartford was the city's center of style and elegance.
 From the 1930's to the 60's, fashionable dress shops, shoe and jewelry stores and men's clothiers lined both sides of the block between Main and Trumbull Streets. Among them was a dress shop known as ''Florence Travis'' and owned by a pair of transplanted New Yorkers, Bill Travis, and the shop's namesake, his wife, Florence.
 They were the children of retailers. Ms. Travis's father owned a successful line of boys' and girls' clothing, known as ''Sunny Lee'' and ''Sandra Lee'' and Mr. Travis was the son of a dress-shop owner. A year after their marriage in 1936, they decided to go into the family business and open a shop in Hartford that would feature the best in New York fashions.
 They were trend setters in Hartford retailing. Their store was one of the first small shops to offer charge accounts, and the Florence Travis shop helped the young women working in nearby insurance companies to buy and wear the latest New York fashions on credit by introducing one of the first layaway plans.
 Sara Greenberg, who worked for Ms. Travis for 20 years, recalled how she sold by example. ''She would wear it and everybody would want it,'' Ms. Greenberg said.
 From a small shop on Pratt Street, the couple moved to larger quarters on the same street and opened Florence Travis branches in Bloomfield, Middletown and West Hartford. Pratt Street went into decline around the time the anchor department stores in downtown Hartford began moving to the suburbs and the Pratt Street store closed in 1973, three years before Mr. Travis' death. The West Hartford shop operated until 1996.
 Ms. Travis died March 5. She was 88.

Restoring Gardens, Even Twain's
 When the restoration of Mark Twain's Hartford home was begun in the late 1950's, Mary Edwards wanted the landscaping to be as authentic as the home's furnishings.
 She researched and identified the shrubs, flowers, trees and vines that were on the grounds when the Samuel Clemens family lived in the house and searched the countryside to make certain the gardens and the contents of the house's large conservatory would reflect the proper period.
 Ms. Edwards was a Hartford native, was educated at the Oxford School, Vassar College and the Rhode Island School of Design and was a landscaper specializing in residential work. 
 She joined the Mark Twain House Board of Trustees in 1956 and served until 1978 when she became a trustee emeritus. In addition to her work on the Mark Twain grounds, she restored the gardens at other historic homes in the Hartford area, including the Webb House in Wethersfield and the Phelps-Hathaway House in Suffield. She was a member of the Hartford Garden Club and the Sow and Reap Garden Club of the South Congregational Church in Granby.
 Ms. Edwards and her mother, the late Helen Bunce Edwards, were longtime supporters of the Hartford Art School of the University of Hartford. Ms. Edwards was a trustee of the school from 1958 to 1965. 
 Ms. Edwards died Jan. 15. She was 91.

Caring for His Hometown
 Dr. William Finkelstein was known as the dean of internists and the father of medical education at St. Mary's Hospital in Waterbury. 
 He served the hospital in his hometown as chief of medicine, president of the medical staff, director of medical education and cardiology.
 Born in Waterbury, Dr. Finkelstein was the valedictorian of Crosby High School's Class of 1925 and received his undergraduate and medical education at Harvard. After a residency at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York, he came home to Waterbury in 1934 and practiced medicine there for the next 54 years until his retirement at the age of 80 in 1988.
 As a member of the American College of Physicians, Dr. Finkelstein always considered the mentoring of those who followed him in medicine as his first priority, according to his family. 
 For many years, he provided scholarships to help Waterbury students attend college and he recently sponsored an exchange student from Kazan Medical School in Russia to study at the Yale Primary Residency Program at St. Mary's Hospital. A research fellowship has been established in the residency program in Dr. Finkelstein's name and the hospital's medical library is also named for him.
 Dr. Finkelstein died at St. Mary's Hospital May 18. He was 95.

Understanding the World
 Marjorie Anderson was executive director of the World Affairs Council of Connecticut from 1974 until her retirement in January. The council, based in West Hartford, is a nonprofit, nonpartisan organization that promotes the understanding of global affairs.
 During Ms. Anderson's three decades as executive director, she established the council's executive forum, which attracted many prominent speakers to its foreign policy discussions, among them former President George H.W. Bush, former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger and diplomats from many nations.
 Ms. Anderson was also active in the League of Women Voters and was president of the state league from 1977 to 1979. In 1980, she ran unsuccessfully for Congress as a Republican in the solidly Democratic First Congressional District and she was a member of the West Hartford Town Council in the 1980's. 
 At the World Affairs Council, Ms. Anderson directed the Model United Nations and Great Decisions programs and was responsible for administering the State Department's International Visitor program in the Hartford area.
 Born in Liverpool, England, Ms. Anderson came to the United States as an evacuee during World War II. She graduated from Hall High School in West Hartford and studied political science at the University of Brussels and the Sorbonne. 
 Ms. Anderson died Oct. 11. She was 75.

A Lover of Hartford's Arts
 Georgette Auerbach Koopman was the great granddaughter of Gerson Fox, the founder of G. Fox and Company, the downtown Hartford department store the family owned from 1845 until it was sold in 1965 by Gerson Fox's granddaughter and Ms. Koopman's mother, Beatrice Fox Auerbach. 
 Ms. Koopman was devoted to Greater Hartford's philanthropies, especially the arts. She was a longtime trustee of the Hartford Art School and the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art. A two-time president of the art school board of trustees, she was the recipient of one of its rarely given honors, the Hartford Art School Medal. She was also a trustee of the Atheneum for many years and an honorary trustee at the time of her death. 
 Ms. Koopman also received the Atheneum's highest honor, the Goodwin Medal, with a citation that noted her ''clarity and decisiveness of mind and her respect for the opinions of others.''
 In addition, Ms. Koopman was on the boards of the Hebrew Home and Hospital, the Connecticut Institute for the Blind, the American School for the Deaf, the Jewish Endowment Foundation and Kingswood-Oxford School. She was a trustee on the boards of both Hartford and St. Francis Hospitals. She and her husband, the late Richard Koopman, also supported many other causes through the family's Beatrice Fox Auerbach Foundation and the Koopman Fund. 
 Ms. Koopman died April 5. She was 87.

High School Coach in 500 Club
 Only eight Connecticut high school basketball coaches have won 500 games or more in their careers, and Joe Reilly is on the list. 
 Mr. Reilly spent most of his coaching career at South Catholic High School in Hartford and won his fifth state championship there in 1991, two days before the Archdiocese of Hartford announced the school would be closed. He coached at South Catholic for 27 years and later coached at Bloomfield and Newington for seven years before retiring in 1998 with an overall record of 512 victories and 288 losses.
 Mr. Reilly's most successful season was 1970 when both his basketball team and baseball team won state championships for South Catholic. He was named coach of the year by the Connecticut High School Coaching Association in 1977 and was selected for the New England Basketball Hall of Fame's inaugural class in 2002.
 Mr. Reilly was part of a coaching family. His brother Gene, who coaches at Portland High School, is also one of the state's eight 500 game winners. In addition, two of Mr. Reilly's sons are coaches: Joe at Bates College in Maine and Luke at East Catholic High School in East Hartford. His daughter Molly Kleinhen coaches a Catholic Youth Organization team in Glastonbury.
 Mr. Reilly died Nov. 2. He was 66.

From Retail to Photography
 Isadore Berson was the founder of two well-known retail chains, the Youth Centre clothing stores and the Bradlees department stores.
 Mr. Berson was also an accomplished, self-taught photographer whose work won him many international prizes from the Photographic Society of America and similar organizations in India, Pakistan, Scotland and South Africa. His photographs have been exhibited at the Chicago Botanic Garden, the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, the University of Hartford and the University of Connecticut Medical Center. 
 He began his business career by opening the first Youth Centre store in Springfield, Mass., in 1937. The company grew into a 17-store chain in Connecticut and Massachusetts by the time it was sold by Mr. Berson in 1978. During the 41 years he operated the stores, Mr. Berson's wife, Marian, was the company's vice president.
 Mr. Berson founded the Bradlees chain in 1958, but sold the company five years later. Bradlees was one of the nation's first discount department stores.
 Mr. Berson died at his West Hartford home on Oct. 27. He was 93.

Aircraft Worker Who Loved Golf
 Porter Pernell came to Hartford from Selma, Ala., when he was 16. After serving in the Korean War as an investigator with a Military Police unit and being trained at the Porter School of Machine and Tool Design in Hartford, he went to work for Pratt & Whitney Aircraft in East Hartford.
 At Pratt & Whitney, Mr. Pernell became the first African-American promoted to foreman and later to superintendent. He worked for the company for 36 years.
 Mr. Pernell was also the first African-American appointed to the board of directors of the East Hartford Aircraft Federal Credit Union and was chairman of the board from 1992 to 1994. He was also a director and chairman of the scholarship committee of the Society of Carbide and Tool Engineering.
 An avid golfer, Mr. Pernell was president of the United Golfers Association for 17 years and a leader in efforts to integrate the sport he loved, according to his family. He was a member of the United Golfers Association Hall of Fame. After his retirement, he lived in Orlando, Fla. and in Bloomfield, where he had made his home for many years.
 Mr. Pernell died June 26. He was 71.

In-Laws Devoted to Winsted
 William Riiska and Joseph O'Brien had a great deal in common. They were Winsted natives, World War II veterans, brothers-in-law for more than 50 years, writers and amateur historians. But most of all, they shared a profound devotion to their home town.
 Although born just three years apart, Joe O'Brien and Bill Riiska didn't know each other growing up. ''We were from the west end and Bill came from the north end of town, and three years make a big age difference when you're young,'' said Marge O'Brien Riiska, Mr. O'Brien's sister and Mr. Riiska's wife.
 Mr. O'Brien was a chief petty officer in the Navy in the Pacific during World War II, and Mr. Riiska was in the Army and landed on Omaha Beach in France shortly after D-Day.
 They came home to northwest Connecticut after the war, married and lived there the rest of their lives. Mr. O'Brien, as a reporter with The Hartford Courant, sometimes worked on a larger stage, covering some of the state's major news stories during 34 years with the newspaper. 
 He was the first reporter to tell of a $400,000 contribution to the national Republican Party following the approval of the merger of International Telephone and Telegraph and the Hartford Fire Insurance Company. Later, his reporting resulted in the exoneration of Peter Reilly, a North Canaan teenager accused of killing his mother. When Mr. O'Brien retired from The Courant, his daughter-in-law recalled that whenever he covered an accident, Mr. O'Brien took a moment to say a prayer for the victims.
 Mr. Riiska's professional life was as an educator, for a short time in Seymour, but for most of his years at a junior high school in Norfolk and at the Regional High School in Winsted that serves students from Norfolk, Barkhamsted, Colebrook and New Hartford. 
 He was deeply involved in Winsted's civic life, serving on many of the city's boards and commissions. He was mayor for four years, city clerk for 14 and acting city manager on several occasions when Winsted found itself between city managers.
 ''He believed that you had to be in government to realize how much valuable time is given to the community by volunteers,'' Ms. Riiska said. Mr. Riiska's favorite volunteer activity was as manager of American Legion baseball teams.
 Mr. O'Brien ended his newspaper career covering his home town and Mr. Riiska retired as city clerk in 1999. Then, both men turned to writing reminiscences. Mr. Riiska wrote about his experiences as a member of a reconnaissance unit in France and Mr. O'Brien wrote about his fond recollections of life in Winsted in the 1930's and 40's for the local newspaper, The Winsted Journal. 
 Mr. O'Brien died March 4 at Charlotte Huntington Hospital in Torrington and Mr. Riiska died two weeks later, March 18, at a hospital in Providence, R.I. Mr. O'Brien was 76 and Mr. Riiska, 79.

A Deep Knowledge of Babies
 Edmund Crelin Jr. was an anatomist at the Yale School of Medicine and a leading authority on infant anatomy.
 In 1969, Dr. Crelin wrote ''Anatomy of the Newborn,'' the first atlas of human infant anatomy, and four years later, he published ''Functional Anatomy of the Newborn.'' The books are considered the foremost reference works on the subject.
 His other specialty was human vocal chords and the origin of modern speech. Dr. Crelin determined that modern speech originated between 500,000 and 1 million years ago. He wrote a book on his research, ''The Human Vocal Tract,'' in 1987.
 Dr. Crelin joined the Yale medical school faculty after receiving his Ph.D. in 1951 and lived in Branford.
 Dr. Crelin died June 21. He was 81.

A Cartoonist of Range
 Gill Fox was a comic book cartoonist, an animator and a syndicated newspaper cartoonist.
 Mr. Fox's career began in the 1930's, considered the golden age of the comic book, as the illustrator of the adventure strip ''Plastic Man.'' He was best known for his widely syndicated single panel comic, ''Side Glances,'' which ran in newspapers for more than 25 years.
 During World War II, Mr. Fox drew ''Bernie Blood'' and ''Dogface'' for Stars and Stripes, a military newspaper.
 In his later years, he was a political cartoonist for The Fairfield Citizen, and in 2003 Mr. Fox won the 2003 New England Newspaper Award for a political cartoon. 
 Mr. Fox died May 15 in Redding. He was 88.

Expert in Transportation Law
 In 1913, when Hugh M. Joseloff was 11 years old, his father and uncles opened a grocery store in Waterbury. By 1929, the brothers owned 500 Economy Stores, which merged with First National Stores, became the Finast chain and is now Stop & Shop.
 Mr. Joseloff worked in the family grocery business for two years after college and law school, but he devoted his career to the law. He was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Yale College in 1923 and was the editor of the Law Review at Yale Law School.
 Mr. Joseloff's specialty was motor carrier and transportation law and he also practiced in such regulatory areas as cable television and public utilities. He appeared before the Interstate Commerce Commission in 1936 and the United States Supreme Court in 1943. He was a prosecuting attorney and judge in the West Hartford town court and a member of Hartford's Draft Board for more than 25 years. An original incorporating attorney of the Motor Transport Association of Connecticut, Mr. Joseloff served two, four-year terms as a member of the state's Transportation Authority.
 Mr. Joseloff died April 29. He was 102.

A Renaissance Man
 William Koneazny was a chef, a radio host, a critic, a saloon keeper, a veteran of two armed forces in two wars, an author of two cookbooks and two books on the Roman Catholic Church. 
 He and his brother, Jack, founded the Peerless Tree Expert Company in 1945, and he was among the first to be licensed as an arborist by the state of Connecticut.
 Beginning in 1947, Mr. Koneazny was a host on the radio talk show, the ''Bill Wicky Hour,'' on a station in Torrington, and he ran a tavern, the Pearly Gates Saloon in Sheffield, Mass., just over the state line. Mr. Koneazny was employed as a restaurant reviewer by two newspapers, The Lakeville Journal and The Connecticut Western Newspaper.
 Mr. Koneazny, a Hartford native, graduated from Weaver High School in 1944 and saw service in the Merchant Marine in World War II and in the Army in the Korean War.
 Mr. Koneazny died June 16. He was 77.

Growing Food for the Hungry
 William Liddell was named one of President George H.W. Bush's ''thousand points of light'' for his volunteer efforts in the 1980's and 90's at the Connecticut Food Bank, which also established an award in his name.
 Farming an acre of land with the help of friends, Mr. Liddell was able to grow more than 30,000 pounds of food annually. He spent 35 years as a horticulturalist with a seed company. 
 From 1956 to 1973, he was a member of the Hamden Board of Education and is remembered for his successful battle against a campaign by some parents to ban J.D. Salinger's ''Catcher in the Rye'' from a high school reading list.
 Mr. Liddell grew up in Massachusetts, graduated from Haverford College in 1941 and served in World War II as an Army cryptologist in Brazil and Italy. He came to Connecticut to earn a Ph.D. in history at Yale in 1953 and lived in the New Haven area for the next five decades. 
 Mr. Liddell died April 26 in Wallingford. He was 84.

Mr. Mayor of Middletown
 Sebastian Garafalo, a Republican, was elected mayor of Middletown, usually a Democratic city, four times. According to his deputy mayor, Stephen Gionfriddo, it didn't matter what party he represented because Mr. Garafalo owed his success to his way with people. He was known as a politician who would argue fiercely at council meetings and then go out for a beer with his allies and opponents.
 Anthony Marino, a Democrat who defeated Mr. Garafalo in 1977 in a close, hard-fought election, said he and Mr. Garafalo were lifelong friends whose grandfathers grew up on the same Middletown street. 
 Mr. Garafalo's public service spanned 31 years, serving the city as a councilman and tax collector as well as mayor. 
 Mr. Garafalo died Jan. 21. He was 71.

HEADLINE: Investors Give Markets a Pre-Christmas Rally

BYLINE: By JEFF SOMMER

 BODY:
The stock market rose in four days of trading last week, as both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed on Thursday at their highest points in the last three years.
 The Commerce Department reported Thursday that personal incomes rose 0.3 percent last month, more than anticipated by many economists, and the University of Michigan said that its index of consumer confidence jumped to an 11-month high in December. 
 These signs of economic buoyancy, as well as a drop in oil prices, contributed to optimism in the stock market, as many investors sought to lock in year-end gains.
 Markets in the United States and in many other Western countries were closed on Friday in observance of the Christmas holiday. By the end of the trading week on Thursday, the Dow had gained 177.20 points, or 1.7 percent, to close at 10,827.12. The S.& P. 500 climbed 15.93 points, or 1.3 percent, to close at 1,210.13. The Nasdaq composite index rose 25.42 points, or 1.2 percent, to close at 2,160.62.
 In the bond market, the price of the benchmark 10-year Treasury note fell slightly, and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 4.22 percent from 4.20 percent the previous week. JEFF SOMMER

HEADLINE: Big Farms Reap 2 Harvests With Aid as Bumper Crop

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN

DATELINE: GURLEY, Neb. 

 BODY:
The roadside sign welcoming people into this state reads: ''Nebraska, the Good Life.'' And for farmers closing out their books at the end of a year when they earned more money than at any time in the history of American agriculture, it certainly looks like happy days.
 But at a time when big harvests and record farm income should mean that Champagne corks are popping across the prairie, the prosperity has brought with it the kind of nervousness seen in headlines like the one that ran in The Omaha World-Herald early this month: ''Income boom has farmers on edge.''
 Despite the fact that farm income has doubled in two years, federal farm subsidies have gone up nearly 40 percent over the same period -- projected at $15.7 billion this year, and $130 billion over the last nine years. And that bounty is drawing fire from people who say that at this moment of farm prosperity, the nation's subsidy system has never made less sense. 
 Even those deeply steeped in the system acknowledge that it seems counterintuitive. ''I struggle with the same question: how the hell can you have such high government payments if farmers had such a great year?'' said Keith Collins, the chief economist for the Agriculture Department.
 The answer lies in the quirks of the federal farm subsidy system as well as in the way savvy farmers sell their crops. Mr. Collins said farmers use the peculiar world of agriculture market timing to get both high commodity prices and high subsidies. 
 ''The biggest reason is with record crops, prices have fallen,'' he said. ''And farmers are taking advantage of that.''
 A farmer can sell his crop early at a high price, say, in a futures contract, and still collect a subsidy check after the harvest if prices are down over all. The money is not tied to what the farmer actually received for his crop. The farmer does not even have to sell the crop to get the check, only prove that the market has dropped below a set rate.
 ''For those who can milk the system, it's been a great year,'' said Kent Miller, whose German great-grandparents were pioneers near this tiny town. Mr. Miller operates a small farm and says he barely made a profit this year on his 3,000 acres of wheat and millet.
 Still, while Mr. Miller is a critic of the system, he is not forgoing aid. Here in Cheyenne County, in the wind-raked western edge of Nebraska, the fields are slumbering for the winter. Most of the harvest is in. Mr. Miller was one of the farmers going into the federal agricultural office to register for new checks after recent swings in the market.
 ''I just signed up for new government payments today,'' Mr. Miller said, standing inside the federal agriculture office for this county. He described the subsidies as little help for ailing family farmers. ''It's a Band-Aid on a large wound.''
 Farm groups say the subsidies provide for a stable food supply, and ensure that major sectors of American agriculture will be competitive on the global market.
 ''When people ask me what the justification for this is, I point out that in nearly every country in the world, you find government involved in the food supply,'' said Bob Young, an economist at the American Farm Bureau Federation, the powerful trade group for major agricultural producers.
 But because nearly 70 percent of the subsidies go to the top 10 percent of agricultural producers, the recent prosperity is not seen or felt among many small to medium-size growers who keep the struggling counties of the Great Plains alive.
 Though some retailers in places like Iowa and Kansas say the boost in farm income promises a good Christmas season, merchants here say they are not experiencing any gains. All around western Nebraska, in places like Chappell or Lorenzo, storefronts are boarded and the merchants who remain complain of the difficulties of surviving.
 Even though Cheyenne County is one of the few bright spots in the economic desert of the rural Plains, its recent job boom has nothing to do with agriculture. A major outdoor goods company, Cabela's, has its world headquarters in Sidney, and its giant retail store is a draw off Interstate 80.
 ''It's been real slow, and usually December is a good month for us,'' said Brian Thacker, who sells new trucks and cars in Sidney, the biggest town in the county. But he said farmers complain about not having enough money even in good years.
 ''If it's raining, they complain; if the wind is blowing too much, they complain,'' Mr. Thacker said. ''It just seems like they're never happy.''
 Ed Miller, who owns a family feed and seed store in Sidney that caters to small farmers, said his business was not up despite the increase in farm income, because most of the big corporate farms that are doing particularly well do not buy from the local seed dealers.
 So it is not surprising that the current subsidy system is drawing home-grown criticism from people like Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, who says it is only widening the gap between larger and smaller farmers, while not helping rural America.
 The subsidies have also drawn criticism from farmers who grow fruits, vegetables and nuts -- nearly half of American agriculture -- but have nothing like the elaborate safety net in place for corn, cattle, wheat and hog producers.
 ''We don't get payments, and we don't want them,'' said Tom Nassif, president of the Western Growers Association, which represents farmers in the nation's biggest agricultural state, California. ''We believe the marketplace should decide who stays and who goes. And we certainly shouldn't be paying people not to grow.''
 Farm production has doubled over the last 50 years, while the number of farms has fallen by two-thirds. Economists say about 150,000 of America's 2.1 million farms produce 70 percent of the major food crops. But only certain crops -- wheat, corn, cotton, soybeans and sunflowers among them -- qualify for subsidies.
 Every subsidy payment in the country can be found on a Web site put together by the Environmental Working Group, which advocates an overhaul of the farm payment system. The site has become a must-read for farmers, and receives about a million hits a day, the group says.
 According to those records, which are supplied by the Agriculture Department, Mr. Kent Miller, the wheat and millet farmer, received $18,449 in subsidies last year, and a total of $189,254 over the last nine years.
 His neighbor down the road, a wheat farmer named Ronald Jessen, was paid $424,387 over the last nine years, according to the database. Mr. Jessen's father, Raymond, got $485,096 in government money, and his brother, Michael Jessen, got $356,769. They are among the 10 biggest recipients of wheat subsidies in Cheyenne County, which is the state's top wheat county.
 Over all, Nebraska got $7.5 billion in government farm payments over the last nine years.
 The Jessen family wheat farm, despite getting more than $1.2 million in subsidies in that time, is not a gold mine, Ronald Jessen said in an interview. ''You've got to look at all the expenses,'' he said. ''A new combine can cost $200,000. When I do my taxes, the crop breaks even. My profit is what I get from the government.'' 
 Still, Mr. Jessen said he was not proud to be harvesting so much from taxpayers.
 ''Most farmers will tell you they would rather get paid for what's in the elevator rather than from the government,'' he said.
 Other farmers and some critics say that corporations, extended families and partnerships are taking advantage of a system that has little relationship to the ebbs and flows of food supply, and rewards them most in times like now, when farmers should seemingly be able to get by without government help.
 ''It's shocking the extent to which taxpayers subsidize this select group of people whether they're having a good year or bad,'' said Ken Cook, director of the Environmental Working Group. ''I call them the red ink states.''
 Any farm entity -- often a corporation -- can collect up to $360,000 per year. Some of the biggest payments are to farmers who can show a ''historic pattern'' of having grown one of the big commodity crops. In a system that supporters say is intended to ensure economic stability from year to year, farmers do not actually have to grow the crop to get the money. For other payments, a farmer is required to show involvement in helping to run or manage the operation.
 Mr. Kent Miller, who is struggling to run his family farm on his own, says big farms will line their subsidy payroll with family members who have minimal involvement.
 ''Typically, you get 10 relatives who all get the payments, but maybe for 6 of them, the only time they come out to the farm is for Christmas,'' Mr. Miller said.
 While the big farms are having record years, much of rural America is continuing to decline.
 Senator Hagel voted against the 2002 farm bill that is the framework for the current subsidy system. At the time, he said, ''these lopsided payments encourage and subsidize overproduction'' and would ''only widen the disparity gaps between large and small farmers.''
 In a hearing last August, Mr. Hagel said the Great Plains states were in a continued downward spiral, even with record farm income.
 ''Half the rural counties in America lost population in the 2000 census,'' Senator Hagel said in the hearing. ''And three out of four rural counties experienced below-average economic growth, despite the record level of farm subsidies.''
 The highest year for subsidies was 2000, when farmers received $22 billion in payments. Their income was only $47 billion that year. This year, with farm income at $73 billion, is the first year when farmers set a record for earnings, while subsidies were still among the highest in recent years.
 This record year raises the question of what would happen to American agriculture if the government stopped making such large payments. Mr. Collins, the chief economist at the Agriculture Department, said it was possible that farmers would produce the same amount of food in a pure free market.
 Some farmers say they could go cold turkey and make it on their own. Others say they would go under. But the thing many agree on is that working the land, even in good times, is not something they would recommend to their children. 
 ''Out here, the joke is that anyone who tries to get their kid to go into farming is encouraging a form of child abuse,'' Mr. Kent Miller said.

HEADLINE: Before Slicing, Make Sure That the Pie Is Big

BYLINE: By PAUL J. LIM. 
Paul J. Lim is a financial writer at U.S. News & World Report. E-mail: fund@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
DECIDING how much of your money to put into stocks (versus bonds) is often said to be the single most important choice you'll make as an investor. Financial planners and investment experts have spent the better part of the last decade drilling that pearl of wisdom into our heads. But it isn't really true. 
 While allocating assets is certainly more important than stock picking in explaining long-term returns, there is an even more crucial question to answer: How much money should you be investing in the first place? 
 ''Yes, asset allocation is important, but it's not nearly as important as getting money into the market,'' said Patti Brennan, president of Key Financial, a financial planning firm in West Chester, Pa. ''Good savers will be good investors every single time.''
 A study by T.Rowe Price, the mutual fund company, seems to confirm this. Using what are known as Monte Carlo simulations -- computer models that help to predict the probability of achieving a goal -- the company set out to answer a rather complex question: What percentage of preretirement income will our nest eggs be able to produce, safely, based on various rates of savings and different assumptions about asset allocation?
 Here's what the research found: Say you're in your 30's with 30 years to go before retiring. Assume that you've already saved a year's worth of your current pretax salary. (In other words, if you make $100,000 a year, you've banked that amount.) Say you plan to invest conservatively during your working years, with 40 percent of your holdings in stocks and 60 percent in bonds. Then assume that you will downshift even more during retirement, to 20 percent stocks and 80 percent bonds. 
 According to the simulation, there is a very good probability -- 80 percent, to be exact -- that you would be able to replace 41 percent of your preretirement income once you left the work force. That assumes you're able to save and invest 15 percent of your salary annually during your working years. This figure includes all sources of savings, including your 401(k) money, 401(k) matches from your employer and profit sharing.
 Now say you decided to become more aggressive, putting 60 percent of your money in stocks and 40 percent in bonds during your career and then moving to 40 percent stocks, 60 percent bonds in retirement. Although you are now taking on considerably more risk, the study by T.Rowe Price says this strategy is highly likely to let you replace 43 percent of your income in retirement -- a difference of just two percentage points.
 On the other hand, if you increased your annual savings rate modestly, to 20 percent from 15 percent, you'd be able to replace 52 percent of your income -- and that's under the original, conservative asset allocation strategy that emphasized bonds. 
 The results tell us a couple of things. First, investing more money will give you more bang for your buck than investing a smaller pot of money more aggressively. It's just the nature of investing. Moreover, you will have to save a large percentage of your salary -- probably far more than most households assume -- if you hope to replace most of your income in retirement.
 Even if you saved 25 percent of pretax income a year starting in your 30's, there's a very good chance you would be able to replace only 65 percent of income. And that's if you had already banked a year's worth of salary and invested 60 percent of the money in stocks and 40 percent in bonds during your working years.
 If you've managed to bank three times your annual salary by your 30's, you could replace 87 percent of income, based on the same assumptions. ''The reason for that is compound interest,'' said Rande Spiegelman, vice president for financial planning at the Schwab Center for Investment Research. ''Every dollar you've already saved will have a big impact on your future returns.''
 The Schwab research center did its own study of how much investors should be saving, based on traditional assumptions like an 8 percent annual rate of return and 2.5 percent annual inflation. Its conclusion was that people in their 20's should be saving 10 to 15 percent of their salary each year, while people in their 30's who have nothing in the bank should start saving 15 to 25 percent. And those in their early 40's who previously neglected to save would need to set aside 25 to 35 percent. 
 SOME investors may look at these numbers and throw up their hands. ''It can make people feel like it's a hopeless proposition,'' said Lori Lucas, director of 401(k) participant research at Hewitt Associates. But Ms. Lucas said Hewitt's own research concluded that ''if you save a couple percent more a year and are willing to retire a couple years later, that can have a major positive impact on your results.'' 
 All of these studies seem to point to another truth: investors should look everywhere for that incremental 2 percent. If you're not maximizing 401(k) contributions, you should. And if your company offers matching 401(k) money, you may be able to raise your contribution by less than 2 percent to achieve the additional savings.
 Failing to take these steps, particularly at an early age, may mean the difference between living comfortably in retirement and having to work a few more years, said Christine Fahlund, a senior financial planner at T.Rowe Price, who ran the probability studies. That is why it's important to ''moderate your lifestyle as early in life as you can,'' she said.

HEADLINE: Everything's Up to Date in Korea's Ancient Capital

BYLINE: By ANDREW YANG

 BODY:

Why Go Now
 Because Seoul is the new Tokyo. With Seoul's proximity to Beijing and Tokyo (both less than two hours away by air), this city of about 10 million is becoming the focal point of transportation and business in northern Asia. Think of it as a capital with the culture and excitement of Tokyo, but less hectic and easier on the pocketbook. It was host to the 1988 Summer Olympics, and is becoming more international and cosmopolitan. 
 The commercial conglomerates of Seoul, like Samsung and SK Telecom, have kept the city enriched with a healthy diet of skyscrapers and world-class cultural institutions. As the country's economy has stabilized since the late 1990's, design-centered museums, art galleries, restaurants, bars and boutique hotels are thriving. 
 A quick flip through the Korean versions of GQ and Teen Vogue in any of the scores of Starbucks stores or a stroll down Cheongdam-dong past the fashion boutiques quickly reveal that Seoul is poised for a hipper future. Any of the fashionable enclaves such as Apgujeong, Cheongdam or Itaewon could easily be mistaken for West Hollywood, or the Harajuku, and young Koreans are likely to know as much about Britney Spears as they do about Korean politics. 

Where to Stay
 The 1 W Seoul-Walkerhill, this hotel chain's first outpost in Asia, opened last September. Perched atop Mount Acha, right on the bank of the Han River (21 Gwangjang-dong, Gwangjin-gu, (82-2) 2465 2222, or on the Web at www.wseoul.com) the W offers a most stunning and seductive view of the city. With floor-to-ceiling windows, the remote-controlled electric curtains automatically open in the morning to reveal the river and the rest of the city skyline, almost within arm's reach. The hotel offers two restaurants as well as a spa, gym and a third-floor pool that is situated with a city view and feels like an extension of the river. Doubles, $308, at 1,084 won to the United States dollar. 
 The 2Shilla Seoul, 202 Jangchung-dong 2-ga, Jung-gu, (82-2) 2233 3131 or on the Web at seoul.shilla.net, is a luxurious 507-room hotel with a more traditional Korean decor. Doubles, $275 and up. 
 For a location across the Han River, closer to the newer parts of the city, the 3Coex Intercontinental, 159 Samsung-dong Kangnam-ku, seoul-coex.intercontinental.com, (82-2) 3452 2500 is a modern hotel near the Coex convention center and mall, Korea's largest. Doubles, about $325.

Where to Eat
 As you might expect, kimchi, that spicy fermented cabbage, is ubiquitous in Seoul restaurants. It is an option for breakfast, lunch and dinner, and will often be served regardless, depending on where you eat. Other popular Korean food includes bulgogi, marinated barbequed beef and galbi, marinated ribs, which are cooked on a heated pot at the dinner table. 
 For the most authentic Korean cuisine, try 4Jihwaja, San 14-67, Jangchung-dong 2-ga, Jung-gu, (82-1) 2 2269 5834, located within the National Theater of Korea. The main dish is gujeolpan, a nine-sectioned plate of food that can be mixed in a rice or wheat wrap. Multicourse dinners $25cost to $100 a person. 
 For more adventurous fare, 5Cafe 74, 83-20, Cheongdam-dong, (82-2) 542 7412, serves an Italian-Eastern fusion cuisine. Italian food is to Koreans what Chinese food is to New Yorkers. While a smattering of fusion cuisines exists in Seoul, such as kimchi-flavored risotto (a harrowing experience), Cafe 74 is quite a reliable way to experience the Korean version of Italian food. Dinners cost between $22 and $32 a person. 
 The crowds are flocking to 6Mr. Chow, 91-6, Nonhuyn-dong, Gangnam-gu, (82-2) 517 2100, the first Asian outpost of the chain that currently has locations in New York, Los Angeles and London. While it's hard to get a table without calling well in advance -- the restaurant has been so crowded that it has been known to take reservations just to have a drink at the bar -- the couches of the dark, cozy bar make an ideal place for a nightcap. Dinners cost around $35 to $120 a person. 

What to Do During the Day
 A popular place for antiques and historic shops is Insadong, an arts district north of downtown. A thoroughly modern arts center, the 7Insa Arts Alley, opened a new building this month, across the street from the Insa Art Center, (82-2) 736 1020. With a Guggenheim-like spiral network but set around an open courtyard, the new building shows the work of young, experimental Korean artists, and is a design collaboration between Gabriel Kroiz, an American architect, and Moongyu Choi, a Korean architect. 
 For a spectacular view of the city, go to the gleaming, 1,200-foot-tall 8Seoul Tower, Namdaemun-ro 1-ga, Jung-gu, (82-2) 775 6222, in Namsan Park. Also near Namsan Park is a recent addition to city's cultural landscape, 9Leeum, Samsung Museum of Art, 747-18, Hannam-dong, Yongsan-gu, or www.leeum.org, which opened in October with a campus of three buildings each designed by a different architect. Rem Koolhaas, Jean Nouvel and Mario Botta created a stunning assemblage of drastically different designs. The museum shows the Samsung Cultural Foundation's top-notch contemporary and traditional art collection. The museum is free to the public but is open by appointment only. Located in a densely populated residential neighborhood on Yongsan Mountain, it is difficult to find, even for experienced cabdrivers, so be sure to note that it is near the Grand Hyatt. 

What to Do at Night
 Our best source of intelligence came from the bartender at 1Woobar, (82-2) 2022 0022, a multilevel lounge complete with silver-pod D.J. booth and private cabanas on the ground floor of W Seoul-Walkerhill (see above). During the day, the main boulevards in Cheongdam-dong are the fashionable places to shop, she explained, but at night, the locals come out to enjoy themselves there. Some of the best bars and clubs in Seoul are off Cheongdam-dong. Jazz clubs are the rage in Seoul, and one of the less kitschy venues is 10Hwa Su Mok, 125-24 Cheongdam-dong, Gangnam-gu, (82-2) 548 5429, which means Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday or fire, water and wood, in Korean. The jazz is superb, and the crowds tend to be more low-key. 
 Itaewon, a neighborhood in the center of the city north of the river, is where you will find 11Areno, 395, 5-ga, Namdaemun-ro, Chung-gu, (82-2) 317 3244, a popular dance club inside the Millennium Seoul Hilton. Nearby, inside the Hamilton Hotel, you'll find 12 Limenight, 119-25, Itaewon-dong, Yongsan-gu, (82-2) 790 0588, a big 1980's-style club where international bankers and local hipsters mix, as well as 13J Bar, a quieter and more funky bar and lounge in an alley adjacent to the hotel.

Where to Shop
 UN Studio, a Dutch architectural firm, recently outfitted the 14Galleria department store, 494, Apgujeong-dong, Gangnam-gu, (82-2) 3449 4114, or www.galleria.co.kr, with a massive new facade with 4,300 white discs. At night, it is easily the most luminous sight in Apgujeong, as it flashes images and patterns in a multitude of colors for the store, which carries such brands as Christian Dior and Chanel. 
 From the Galleria, Apgujeong-dong runs south until it intersects Cheongdam, where Western luxury retailers have their boutiques. Farther down, visitors will find Boon the Shop, a popular Korean retailer. The first Boon opened three years ago as a single-level retail space designed by the New York architectural firm of LOT/EK. In August, the store opened a four-story shop, 151F Boon the Shop Building, Cheongdam-dong, Gangnam-gu, (82-2) 317 0397, that immerses shoppers in the store's stock of Burberry Prorsum and Commes des Garcons. 
 One of the city's most talked-about shops, 16Mue, 93-6 Cheongdam-dong, Gangnam-gu, (82-2) 3446 8074, occupies an exquisite three-level space that, along with its smattering of Martin Margiela and Viktor & Rolf's clothes, includes fashion-architectural theatrics by the designer Minsuk Cho such as translucent concrete walls and 20-foot-high multimedia projections.

How to Stay Wired
 Cheap Internet cafes can be found scattered around the city. Most charge about $1 an hour. Free Internet access can be found within the Seoul Information Center, 31 Daepyungno 1-ga, Jung-gu, (82-2) 731-6337, located on the second floor of 17 Seoul City Hall.

Your First Time or Your 10th
 Slightly north of downtown is 18Gyeongbokgung, end of Sejong-ro, (82-2) 732 1931, the main palace during the Chosun Dynasty (1392-1910) in Seoul. Visitors who come from the Gwanghwamun subway station can instantly see down Sejong-ro to the majestic gates of the palace, which are framed by the Bukaksan Mountains. 
 The grounds are expansive, and include historic Korean, pagodalike structures as well as the 19 National Folklore Museum, 1-1, Sejongno, Jongno-gu, (82-2) 720 3137. But when one stands at the palace gates, the juxtaposition is jarring: In the foreground is 500 years of Korean history, and glittering in the background is the rest of Seoul, with its ultramodern skyscrapers arrayed across the horizon. 

How to Get There
 In 2002, the city opened Inchon International Airport on an island about an hour west of the city, leaving the city's other airport, Gimpo, to handle domestic flights. Inchon acts as a major hub for a number of airlines such as United and Korean. 
 During peak seasons, fares to Seoul from New York can be as much as $1,300. The best time to travel is in March and April, and in September and November. The city experiences the mildest temperatures in those months, and the fares are around $900. United, Northwest and Korean Airlines all offer direct flights from Kennedy Airport in New York to Tokyo, which take approximately 13 hours, and then another two-hour jump to Seoul. Less direct flights can take up to 25 hours or more. 

How to Get Around
 Traffic is notoriously bad in Seoul, particularly in rush hour, so use the city's subway systems, which are clean and cost around 85 cents a trip (5:30 a.m. to midnight, and until 1 a.m. on weekends).

HEADLINE: Regrets? They Have a Few.

BYLINE: By JESSE GREEN

 BODY:

MARIO CANTONE
 After appearing in the Roundabout Theater Company's revival of ''Assassins,'' Mr. Cantone brought his take-no-prisoners one-man show ''Laugh Whore'' to Broadway's Cort Theater. The show is scheduled to close on Jan. 2, but was taped for future broadcast on Showtime.
 ''I would have worked out a better contract, because it's kind of pitiful what I'm making. I'm a bad businessman. And though I love the Cort, the star dressing room is for Barbie. It's like, 'Hi, where's Ken and Skipper?' It's so small, and visitors have no place to go. And why did I insist on a two-act thing with an intermission instead of just making it 90 minutes? To get through it, you really have to live like a nun. I can't drink, I can't smoke. I'm not even supposed to talk, which is hard for me. At this point I'm like, Jesus Christ, just give me a drink.''

SARAH JONES
 Ms. Jones wrote ''Bridge and Tunnel,'' a play that consisted of her startling impersonations of 14 would-be poets at an immigrant poetry slam. A hit of the Off Broadway season, ''Bridge and Tunnel'' closed in mid-August but is scheduled to open on Broadway in April. 
 ''I should have kept it going through the Republican convention. It's a show about immigrants, after all. I would have invited Arnold Schwarzenegger to be one of the poets.''

TONY KUSHNER
 ''Caroline, or Change,'' with words by Mr. Kushner and music by Jeanine Tesori, sold out its run at the Public Theater but closed after four months on Broadway. Also in 2004, HBO's ''Angels in America'' won seven Emmy Awards, including one for Mr. Kushner's script. 
 ''We got 'Caroline' to Broadway and 120,000 people saw it and we got the CD made, and the show's doing well in Los Angeles. Broadway economics is a disaster -- Off Broadway not much better -- but I wouldn't change anything I did in 2004, at least not professionally. I shouldn't have let the stress of getting 'Caroline' to Broadway make me gain 20 pounds, knowing that I might well have to be on national TV for the Emmy Awards. But thanks to Weight Watchers I've now lost 26 pounds.''

BARRY HUMPHRIES
 An Australian actor who has appeared in many reputable plays and movies, Mr. Humphries is best known here as the mauve-haired ''gigastar'' Dame Edna Everage. He returned to Broadway this year in ''Dame Edna: Back With a Vengeance!,'' now playing at the Music Box. 
 ''I regret Dame Edna's insistence on dominating the entire show and not allowing me a look in. One day I'd quite like to do in New York one of the shows I do in England and Australia, where I normally play six or seven other characters, including Sir Les Patterson, an Australian diplomat who is given to habits of intemperance and is rather well endowed, as ladies whose eyes stray to his powder-blue trousers can attest. But Dame Edna won't let me. She further accuses me of embezzlement.''

DAME EDNA EVERAGE
 According to her biography, Dame Edna is ''probably the most popular and gifted woman in the world today.'' She also has a mighty arm, hefting hundreds of her signature gladioli into the audience during each performance's finale.
 ''One thing I would change is my producer, Barry Humphries, who took up with me years ago and had me sign something that turned out to be binding in perpetuity. Like all producers, he thinks he's an artist; I just smile and ignore him. There is also a problem with my show that has been happening with increasing and spooky regularity. When I pick subjects from the audience for my empowerment and finally summon them onto the stage, very often they say, 'You picked me before.' A very distinguished banker was onstage the other night and I had him dress up as my son, Ricky, in leather and spikes. He whispered to me, 'I was the Queen Mother last time.' And I hate to say it, because they are my signature, but the gladdies cost a fortune, even for a rich woman like I! I'm throwing thousands of dollars into the audience every night. If I could have it to do over, I would change from gladioli to some other flower, something more readily available in the depth of winter. I've thought of cacti. Or thistles. Or nettles.''

BERNADETTE PETERS
 After 33 previews and 451 regular performances, the Broadway revival of ''Gypsy'' starring Ms. Peters as Rose closed in May. 
 ''It was exhausting, but I wish we had kept doing the show. We could have gone deeper.''

LARRY KRAMER
 The Worth Street Theater's revival of ''The Normal Heart'' -- Mr. Kramer's 1985 play about the beginning of the AIDS crisis -- opened in April. Despite strong reviews, talk of a Broadway transfer and full houses (heavily ''papered'' with freebies), it closed after Joanna Gleason unexpectedly left to join rehearsals for the musical ''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels.'' 
 ''I sensed going in that the original director wasn't going to work out but I was too anxious to get the play on and said nothing. The actors were exceedingly unhappy, and he had to be replaced. Another big problem was money. I was assured there was enough in place when we started -- $400,000 or something -- to get us through the production. It wasn't true, and I should have gotten more assurances on that matter. Now I'm told that happens all the time, but I was naive. That in the end killed us, because they didn't have money to advertise. And then Joanna left suddenly. We didn't have an understudy so we went dark for two weeks while Lisa Kron learned the part, and she went in very fast, but it was too late. The momentum was gone. Even though the houses were always full, and there were always people in standing room! But it turned out the play was heavily papered, and I didn't know. I should have checked on that early. It breaks my heart. I have plenty of plays left in me, but what's the point? I will never write another play.'' JESSE GREEN
