HEADLINE: Cuba Counters Prostitution With AIDS Programs

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

DATELINE: HAVANA 

 BODY:
Like many prostitutes who ply their trade in the darkened bars and discos near tourist hotels here, Maria says she does not go out every night. But whenever money gets tight and her 12-year-old son is hungry, she puts on a red miniskirt, puts rouge on her lips and heads for El Conejito bar, a thinly disguised rendezvous point.
 ''Most of the tourists come to look for girls, tobacco, you know, the things they cannot get in their country,'' she said. ''They say the Cuban girls are very hot.''
 Maria, who is 36 and insisted that her last name not be published, said she worried about contracting AIDS and forced her clients to use condoms, every time. She is knowledgeable about the disease, having learned about it through the government's anti-AIDS program, and she was tested twice during a stint in jail last year for prostitution. Since then, she said, she voluntarily gets tested regularly at the free health clinics. 
 A decade after an economic collapse forced thousands of young women and men into prostitution, Cuba has become something of an anomaly in Latin America: a destination for sex tourists where AIDS has yet to become an uncontrollable pandemic. 
 Cuba has the lowest infection rate in the Western Hemisphere, less than 0.1 percent of the population, according to the World Health Organization. The infection rate in the United States is six times that in Cuba, and Cuba's rate is far below that in many neighboring countries in the Caribbean and Central America. 
 That is not to say the disease is not spreading in Cuba, and some outside the government say a thriving sex industry has contributed to its spread. On July 3, 1998, the Cuban government said 1,980 people had tested positive for the virus that causes AIDS since 1986. Since 1998, 3,879 more have been discovered to have the virus, according to statistics released by health officials; in just six years, the number of newer cases has nearly doubled. 
 ''I think the epidemic has kept growing,'' said the Rev. Fernando de la Vega, a Roman Catholic priest at the Iglesia Montserrat, who runs a program for people with AIDS at the Iglesia Montserrat in Old Havana. ''We have to face facts. There is a portion of tourists, mostly Europeans, who come to Cuba for a good time, and a good time includes sexual activity.''
 Cuban health officials acknowledge that the number of infections has increased, as in most countries, but they say the overall rate is very low for a population of 11 million. 
 ''Prostitution is not an aggravating problem in the epidemic,'' said Dr. Rigoberto Lopez, the director of the National Center for the Care of Persons with HIV-AIDS, adding that only a handful of the 280 patients he cares for at the main sanitarium for AIDS patients in Havana, known as Los Cocos, are former sex workers. 
 For more than a decade, the government has run an intense public-education campaign in schools and on state-owned television and radio stations, promoting the use of condoms and informing people about how H.I.V., the human immunodeficiency virus, is transmitted. The system of free primary care clinics in Cuba, a Communist country, has also led to the early detection of the virus in many people, Cuban and United Nations officials say.
 In the early 1990's, Cuba quarantined people with the virus, and those discovered to be infected are still required to stay three to six months in one of Cuba's 13 government AIDS sanitariums, where they receive treatment and counseling on how to survive with the virus and how to avoid passing it along. Once they leave the hospitals, the patients are closely monitored in their homes by social workers, officials say. 
 A decades-old United States embargo on selling Cuba many medical supplies has crimped the country's ability to provide drugs to patients, but the government has replicated some advanced retroviral medicines used to fight AIDS, providing them at no cost. This, too, has slowed the epidemic.
 United Nations officials who track AIDS say Cuba has done a better job than most countries at corralling the disease. ''Certainly there has been an increase in AIDS, but it is not big, not like you see in the Dominican Republic, or Haiti, or in Puerto Rico,'' said Paloma Cuchi, who oversees the United Nations AIDS program in Latin America. ''They have a very good medical infrastructure, and people have access to care and prevention.'' 
 The low levels of the virus in Cuba and the inexpensive price of sex compared with other places have made the island a destination for male tourists seeking women. 
 In Havana, the sex trade becomes obvious after sunset. Around 10 p.m., young women in skimpy attire begin gathering outside the main tourist hotels, asking men if they would like to go to nightclubs, where a sex-for-cash proposition is usually made.
 Sex workers, known as jinateras, seeking tourist clients can also be seen outside certain discos and bars, or hitchhiking along the Malecon, the main highway separating Havana from the sea, to proposition tourists.
 In interviews, several jinateras said the brutal economic conditions in Cuba under an American embargo, where monthly state salaries do not buy enough food for a month, had pushed them into the business. 
 Most work for themselves, and on most days, they say, they can count on $50 to $75 from Europeans, plus meals, drinks and gifts.
 The government periodically cracks down on prostitution, they said. Undercover police officers work the streets and clubs, looking for prostitutes. An arrest can mean a two-year prison term.
 But some women said they kept relationships with pimps, or chulos, to pay off the police. These men lurk outside hotels and guide tourists to bars where the women wait. One recent night, a chulo was working the fringes of the Melia Cohiba, a hotel, trying to persuade men to go to the Copa Room, a nearby disco in the Riviera Hotel.
 ''If you see a girl you like inside, you tell me and she can come to your room,'' said the man, who gave his name only as Carlos. ''The hotels usually do not allow the jinateras upstairs,'' he added, winking. ''But everything is possible with money.''
 For the most part, the women who work as prostitutes say they are looking to link up with someone who can take them out of Cuba, or provide them with a steady income. Many are part-time prostitutes, who go out only when their meager state salaries run out.
 Hermita, 28, a secretary at a school who earns about $8 a month, was trolling for tourists near the Hotel Inglaterra in Old Havana on a recent evening. She has a 2-year-old daughter from a marriage that did not last, and she said she needed money for food, clothing and shoes. 
 ''When I am with a foreigner, I try to be with them for the whole time they are here,'' she explained. ''Above all it's about the money.'' Ideally, however, she would ''meet a foreigner, marry him and be able to travel, without having to leave the country forever.'' 
 Outside Jardinas 1830, an outdoor disco on the Malecon also known as a place to pick up jinateras, Maria A. and her sister, Yamilet, two young women from Camaguey Province, were showing off their legs and midriffs to tourists who approached the club, hoping someone would invite them in for a drink or take them to a rooming house for the night.
 Maria A., 23, said she gave up working as a hairdresser and started sleeping with tourists two years ago. She said she came close to striking it rich when an Italian tourist several years older than she had agreed to pay for an apartment for her. But they quarreled on a subsequent visit, she said, and now she is on the hunt again. In the meantime, she collects $40 to $70 a night from any tourist she can lure to a rooming house with which she has a mutually beneficial arrangement.
 ''Nobody does this because they like it,'' she said, drawing on a cigarette. ''I would marry someone to get out.''
 Asked about AIDS, Maria shrugged. ''We take care of ourselves, protect ourselves, use condoms,'' she said. ''I get a test from the doctor every six months.''

HEADLINE: Cuba Meets Peru, Over a Melting Pot

BYLINE: By Louise Kramer. 
This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com

 BODY:
THE restaurant business is famous for flops. More than two thirds of all restaurants either close or change hands within the first five years, and some even fail to make it to their first anniversary, according to the New York City chapter of the New York State Restaurant Association.
 Nevertheless, there is a seemingly limitless supply of would-be restaurateurs in the city who are eager to take a chance on the business, and some, like Sofia Luna, an immigrant from Lima, Peru, are managing to beat the odds. Ms. Luna, 27, is poised to turn her family's minichain of five Cuban restaurants, Sophie's Cuban Cuisine, into a regional and perhaps even national chain. 
 This month, the first Sophie's outside the financial district opened in Midtown, on Madison Avenue between 33rd and 34th Streets. By next spring, Ms. Luna, who has emerged as the chain's business manager and driving force, hopes to start selling franchises.
 ''We've run out of brothers and sisters to run them,'' she joked.
 Some of the most successful entrepreneurs seem to be born with a knack for business, and Ms. Luna appears to be among them. On a recent tour of the Madison Avenue Sophie's before it opened, Ms. Luna, a trim woman in a pink sweater, with large hoop earrings and a neat ponytail, recounted with a note of pride in her voice how she negotiated several months' free rent to provide time for construction.
 It was a family decision not to sell Peruvian food. ''It's very tasty,'' Ms. Luna said, but added that it is somewhat difficult to produce on a large scale. Moreover, she did not think New Yorkers were familiar with the cuisine, and worried that there would not be enough demand.
 Cuban food turned out to be a good bet. The city has few Cuban lunch spots among its 23,000 food-service establishments. Almost from the day the first Sophie's opened on Greenwich Street, near the World Trade Center, in 1997, it was packed. Sophie's restaurants feature classic Cuban dishes like stewed chicken, roast pork and shredded beef. They are served cafeteria style, and cost $7, including a helping of rice and beans. The menu also includes classic Cuban sandwiches for $5.
 During every weekday lunch hour, the tables at the downtown restaurants are filled with a melting pot of financial district employees, municipal workers and executives. The two largest Sophie's branches, on Pearl Street and Chambers Street, have annual sales of $1.5 million each, according to Ms. Luna. That is close to the average sales of a McDonald's. Each restaurant goes through 700 pounds of rice, 300 pounds of beans, and 280 pounds of pork a week. Limited hours -- the restaurants close at 7:30 p.m. and are shut on Sundays -- and spare decor keep costs down. ''We are successful because we are not a fancy restaurant,'' Ms. Luna said. ''We provide good food, it's fast and we keep our quality high.''
 E. Charles Hunt, executive vice president of the New York City chapter of the state restaurant association, said that restaurants often fail because of ''poor selection of a location, undercapitalization, and lack of experience.''
 Ms. Luna started getting her experience early on. Her grandparents, with whom she lived, owned a restaurant in Lima and did much of their cooking at home. After she came to New York in 1990, she, her two sisters and a brother would help their mother cook Peruvian specialties, like seviche and canario beans, to sell at soccer games in Queens.
 A family friend persuaded the clan to think bigger. By pooling their funds and borrowing, the family raised $200,000 to invest in the first Sophie's. The subsequent ones have been financed with profits from the business.
 Like most downtown businesses, Sophie's was affected by the attack on the World Trade Center. One restaurant was shut for six months. Another, the closest to ground zero, never recovered from the loss of business, and the family shut it down. But no one at any of the restaurants was hurt that day; by chance, Ms. Luna, a sister, and their mother had skipped what had become a regular breakfast meeting at a deli in the World Trade Center. Ms. Luna was at St. John's University, where she was taking courses in restaurant management.
 That fall, when many businesses were avoiding downtown, Ms. Luna signed a lease for the restaurant on Chambers Street. ''We called the landlord directly and got a good lease,'' she said. ''We knew downtown was going to get back to the way it was before.''

HEADLINE: China Expands. Europe Rises. And the United States . . .

BYLINE: By FRED KAPLAN. 
Fred Kaplan is the national security columnist for Slate.

 BODY:
IT'S a risky business to predict the decline of the American empire. Ask Paul Kennedy, the Yale historian, who issued such a forecast in his 1987 book, ''The Rise and Fall of Great Powers,'' only to witness an almost immediate American resurgence.
 Yet the signposts, at the end of this year, are ominous. As an economic power, the United States no longer sets the rules, much less rule the game. As a military power, it vastly outguns the rest of the world, but has a harder time translating armed might into influence. 
 On March 1, the European Union announced that it was raising import tariffs on a long list of American products, and would go on raising them each month until Congress repealed a subsidy for American exporters that had been ruled illegal by the World Trade Organization. Congressmen railed against this intrusion but finally gave in. Americans realized that, in the global economy they largely created and for 60 years dominated, they could no longer do whatever they wanted.
 Last month, China's president, Hu Jintao, embarked on a 12-day tour of Latin America, and wound up making commitments to invest $30 billion in the region. China is now Brazil's second largest trading partner and Chile's largest export market. In trade, technology, investment, education and culture, China has been displacing the United States all across Asia, and is now starting to do the same in America's backyard.
 There is nothing necessarily alarming about an expansive China or an emergent Europe, except perhaps that they coincide with a growing American dependence on both.
 The United States government spent $650 billion more this year than it raised in revenue, and financed the deficit largely by borrowing from foreign central banks, mainly those of Japan and China. They have been willing creditors because American consumers send much of the money right back by purchasing foreign-made products. It's a neat balancing act, to a point. But the American accumulated debt to foreign investors has now swelled to $3.3 trillion -- 28 percent of gross domestic product, nearly double the share of four years ago.
 In the 1990's, the United States admonished Mexico and Argentina to get their economic houses in order. This month, the Chinese premier gave Washington a strikingly similar lecture.
 These imbalances are not inherently disastrous. The Chinese get something out of the deal, a ready consumer market for their overheated production lines. If they stop lending to the United States, it would cause a deep recession here, but then Americans could not buy as many of their goods, and the recession would ricochet right back to Asia.
 It's a variation on the old joke: If you owe the bank $1 billion, the bank owns you; if you owe the bank $1 trillion, you own the bank.
 But what if another trillion-dollar customer walked into the bank? The bankers might be more willing to foreclose on the debtor, knowing that they could pick up business from the new tycoon.
 The European Union, in many respects, is looking more and more like this new tycoon. Its currency, the euro, has risen in value by 35 percent against the dollar in the last three years.
 Again, that is not necessarily bad. In theory, a falling dollar makes American exports cheaper, attracting demand that then boosts the dollar; a rising euro crimps European exports, which then lowers the euro; equilibrium is restored. In reality, this process unfolds slowly and shakily: in October, for instance, American exports rose, but American imports soared, too. 
 A more serious consequence of the dollar's fall is that the euro has become more rewarding for foreign investors, and they are reacting accordingly. In 2001, Middle Eastern oil-producing countries kept 75 percent of their currency reserves in dollars; now the figure is 61 percent, with much of the rest in euros. Chinese and Russian central bankers are also shifting reserves. This trend, at some point, could set off a spiral: the dollar declines, causing further sell-offs, leading to a further decline, and so on.
 When the dollar has fallen in the past, the United States was a net creditor and there was no serious rival currency. Neither condition holds true now. As The Economist recently put it, ''Never before has the guardian of the world's main reserve currency been its biggest net debtor.'' 
 Financiers and diplomats are beginning to ask: How much longer will the dollar remain the world's principal reserve currency? One could also ask, how much longer can the United States remain, as Madeleine Albright put it, ''the indispensable country'' of world politics?
 This year, the United States spent nearly as much on its military as all other countries combined. No other nation possesses, or aspires to, anything like the reach of American armed forces.
 Yet, if someday the United States finds that it can no longer count on foreigners to bankroll its deficits, it may also find that it can no longer afford a globe-spanning military. The war in Iraq has already stretched America's forces to the limit. In the 1970's and 1980's, when Pentagon strategists spoke of a two-front war, they envisioned having to fight simultaneously in, say, Germany and Korea. Today, they mean Mosul and Falluja.
 About 40 percent of the American troops in Iraq are from the National Guard and Reserves, ''weekend warriors'' who never figured on serving long combat tours. As a result, Guard recruitment has fallen by 30 percent. If there is no large Guard and Reserve, there is no large Army. In short, not only has the Iraq war been harder than many imagined, it has also made going to war elsewhere a less practical option -- and a less credible threat.
 The economic trends are worrisome because they stem not just from market forces but also from politics. As T.R. Reid notes in his new book ''The United States of Europe,'' the euro ''was specifically designed to challenge the global hegemony of the dollar.'' Similarly, China's rivalry with the United States in Asia and Latin America isn't a side effect of economics; it's an explicit ambition.
 These challenges will take decades to unfold, and may not succeed. China may recoil from its manufacturing boom and its excesses; Europeans could revert to age-old continental tensions. The United States may revive itself through changes in policy. 
 Meanwhile, power is not transferring so much as dispersing. It may turn out, if trends continue, that no country or bloc of countries possesses the combination of economic and military power needed to reward the good, deter or punish the bad and impose international rules, order and security. 
 A multipolar world can be a chaotic place. The danger is not so much that the United States may lose power, but that the globe's new rivals may fail to strike and manage a balance of power. End-of-the-year Cassandras traditionally predict doom, gloom and anarchy. This year they're looking less preposterous.

HEADLINE: For a Patchogue Inventor, a Costly Uphill Battle

BYLINE: By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
AT the heart of American enterprise is the ''build a better mousetrap'' axiom: create a fine product, and the market will reward you handsomely.
 Try telling that to Carmine F. Vasile.
 This last year has been a long and trying one for Dr. Vasile, an electrophysicist who lives in Patchogue, a basement inventor and, of late, a lapsed believer in free-market economics. Dr. Vasile (pronounced vah-SILL-ee) believes that he invented the proverbial better mousetrap but that bigger companies and their lawyers have stolen his ideas. ''A great invention doesn't do you any good unless you can afford to protect it all over the world,'' he said. 
 Nineteen years ago, during a period of self-employment between stints at Motorola and the Hazeltine Corporation, an electronics manufacturer in Greenlawn, Dr. Vasile developed a heat-exchange process that had considerable commercial potential, he thought. The process uses a copper coil inserted in a drain to absorb heat from wastewater and transfer it to incoming cold water. The process makes it cheaper to heat cold water.
 Dr. Vasile, who said that during his career he had received about 35 patents on behalf of various employers, including Motorola, Rockwell, Hazeltine and Grumman, holds Patent No. 4,619,311 himself. He assigned the patent to a company called Hydrofilm, a limited partnership he and his wife, Cheryl, operate from their home.
 Dr. Vasile calls his invention a gravity film heat exchanger -- GFX for short. In 1994 Dr. Vasile retired early to focus his entrepreneurial energies on bringing the GFX to market. At the time, Dr. Vasile said, he thought the GFX would finance a comfortable retirement for himself and his wife.
 Five years ago, Dr. Vasile found a partner, Doucette Industries of York, Pa., which manufactured and marketed the device and mailed him monthly royalty checks ranging from $2,000 to $4,000.
 In March, the checks stopped. Doucette announced it was ceasing distribution of the GFX in favor of another product called the Power-Pipe, manufactured by a company called Renewability Inc. in Aurora, Ontario.
 As might be expected, Dr. Vasile was furious, and the Power-Pipe, in his view, is just the GFX under another name.
 ''This is fraud,'' he said. ''I have pictures of the product. Power-Pipe is the same thing as GFX.''
 Dr. Vasile wrote letters, many letters, to everyone involved. He complained to Underwriters Laboratories in Melville, which certified the safety of the GFX; to the Canadian Embassy in Washington; to a trade association of building contractors; and to the Federal bankruptcy court in Central Islip. 
 ''They tell you to watch out for countries like Thailand,'' he said, describing warnings he received about product counterfeiting. ''Nobody tells you about Canada.''
 Dr. Vasile acknowledges that his design is not protected under the Canadian patent system, and he knows that most companies routinely patent their inventions in all markets where they expect to sell or where the product might be manufactured.
 ''I couldn't afford to do that,'' he said. He said he relied on the belief that the GFX design qualified as a trade secret and was thus protected under the Economic Espionage Act of 1996. 
 ''I protected trade secrets for 20 years for companies like Hazeltine,'' Dr. Vasile said. ''When I talk about trade secrets, I know what I'm talking about.''
 Charlie Boeckmann, an aide to Representative Tim Bishop, said that he had written letters on Dr. Vasile's behalf to appropriate F.B.I. officials, asking them to review his claims under the espionage act, and that the F.B.I. told him earlier this month that the claims were being investigated.
 ''If in fact his allegations are correct, we have a serious issue on the federal level.'' Mr. Boeckmann said. 
 John Lebo, the president of Doucette Industries, refused to comment on Dr. Vasile's contentions. ''There really is nothing to discuss with you,'' he said. ''We will comment at the proper venue, and this is not it.''
 Denis Van Decker, a vice president of Renewability Energy, denied that the Power-Pipe was the same product as the GFX. 
 Of Dr. Vasile, he said: ''The man has no credibility. He throws mud at people. The products aren't the same, and our customers know the difference.'' 
 Mr. Van Decker said that arbitrators had ruled against Dr. Vasile in 12 instances, but Dr. Vasile denied that. He said that there had been only three rulings against him and that the arbitration process was incomplete, because he could not afford to pay the costs assessed by the arbitrators. Mr. Van Decker said the issue would be resolved in court. 
 Dr. Vasile has ''done the lion's share of what would be expected of him'' to get his idea successfully commercialized, said an official of the federal Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy, which administered a grant of nearly $100,000 given to Dr. Vasile to help him develop and market his invention. 
 Inventors often confront the problem of defending their patents in other countries, said the official, who spoke on the condition that his name not be used because he was afraid of how his supervisors would react to his comments.
 ''All these guys are disadvantaged trying to get their technology to the market,'' the official said, describing independent inventors. ''They're like the guy in the Greek myth who pushes the boulder up the mountain,'' only to have it roll down again. 
 The official said that there was little the government could do for them, aside from sympathizing with them. His own approach, he said, is to recite motivational speeches made by Vince Lombardi, the Green Bay Packers' coach. ''I told Carmine, 'Don't give up,''' the official said. ''I regularly tell inventors, 'Don't give up.'''
 Dr. Vasile said that he had not given up but that because of financial problems brought on by the GFX, he could not afford to hire a patent lawyer and is presenting a claim in bankruptcy court. 
 Ronald Weiss, a Huntington lawyer who represented Dr. Vasile at his bankruptcy hearing in Central Islip last month, called the case ''particularly complex with several overlapping issues.''
 ''This is a David and Goliath situation, and Carmine is taking on six Goliaths,'' Mr. Weiss said.
 So, instead of financing a comfortable retirement for him and his wife, Dr. Vasile said his efforts to market his GFX invention had depleted ''our lifetime earnings.''
 ''It's been a nightmare,'' he added. ''I blew through my retirement money and my wife's. What I've learned is that people can steal technology at will. Unless you've got money to defend your patent, it's worthless.''
 The GFX patent comes up for renewal next June, but Dr. Vasile is not giving up. ''I'll renew it,'' he said. ''With improvements.'' And things are, in fact, looking up. In July he found a new manufacturer for the GFX, Fuel Cell Components Integrators of Hauppauge, and sales have just gotten under way.

HEADLINE: Kings Park Catches the Imagination of a Literary Journal

BYLINE: By JULIA C. MEAD

 BODY:
LITERARY magazines are generally known for their stunning inability to turn a profit. Often proceeding with an optimistic lack of a business plan, their editors drum up just enough financial backing to publish a few times before the journal disappears, appreciated only by a small, rarefied and fickle audience.
 Then there's Night Train, devoted to keeping alive the waning art of short-story writing through a cunning marketing technique.
 Now in its fourth issue, Night Train is published twice a year by a Boston-based nonprofit group. Its last two issues each had a run of 3,000 copies. 
 But its marketing strategy has worked so well that its subscription base has quintupled since the first issue, and Barnes & Noble doubled its order for the upcoming fifth issue, said Tom Jackson, the magazine's marketing manager and a short-story writer. 
 Mr. Jackson, who works by day writing ad copy for an insurance company based in Peoria, Ill., explained the Night Train strategy in a telephone interview. 
 For each issue, he said, the metaphorical train of the title pulls into a community that has been selected to sponsor the edition. Inside the issue are more than 200 pages of the most provocative short fiction the editors can find. But the photograph on the cover and the last piece of writing are not fiction; they relate to the sponsoring community.
 The selected community gets publicity, and Night Train gets published, with the help of the advertisements in the back of the edition, paid for by business and organizations in the sponsoring town.
 The result looks more like a thick paperback book than a magazine.
 For its most recent issue, out in September, Night Train focused on Kings Park, a hamlet in Smithtown that to outsiders is known mostly for its shuttered, crumbling state psychiatric hospital, which opened in 1885. A bricked-up, Greek-Revival portico at the hospital, framed by out-of-control foliage, is the creepy cover image.
 A 26-page history of the hamlet, written by Rachel Wallack, a Kings Park native, is dotted with photographs taken there. It appears after the contributors' notes, but before the six-page list of 53 local benefactors who wrote checks ranging from $50 to $1,000 to advertise their businesses.
 The benefactors include the local school district and historical museum, which donated $1,000 and $500 respectively; a carver of tombstones who gave $250; a deli, two banks, two funeral homes and the local newspaper, which gave $100 each; and an architect who donated $50. In all, the magazine took in about $10,000.
 Add in revenue from over-the-counter sales and subscriptions, and there is enough -- barely enough -- to keep an obscure literary magazine alive long enough to see another issue, Mr. Jackson said.
 But Night Train is becoming a victim of its own modest success. To meet a growing demand, it must double its next print run. And that necessitates bumping up the sponsorship from the next community, Mr. Jackson explained. 
 As a result, he said, the editors are considering communities for the fifth issue that would raise more money. High on the list is Petaluma, Calif., along with prospects in Pennsylvania and Maine, he said.
 The managing editor, Susan Henderson, lives in Kings Park, which only partly explains the editorial board's choice.
 ''I had to push very hard,'' said Ms. Henderson, who moved there from Pittsburgh.
 In selecting a sponsor, she said, the editors require, first, that the community have a train depot and some railroad-related history, to fit in with the theme of the journal's title. Kings Park is a central stop on the Long Island Rail Road system, one of the most heavily used commuter lines in the nation.
 But the editors also look for little places that are evolving. Kings Park worked, Ms. Henderson said, because its history and shifting identity combine to create a sort of real-life short story.
 The setting is Poe-like -- the looming, ominous-looking hospital, with its darkened, crumbing facade and underground tunnels, and its central role in the hamlet's economic development.
 ''Everyone in town has worked there or knows someone who was locked in that building,'' Ms. Henderson said, noting that the lobotomy was invented there.
 Meanwhile, the hospital is to be torn down, its land to be sold to a developer, and so change is afoot. 
 ''Kings Park is simple and working class, and people have lived here for generations, so we're protective,'' Ms. Henderson said. ''But it has to grow and change with the times, so we're right on the cusp of something. But we don't know what it will become.''
 The magazine's third issue focused on Galesburg, Ill., which is near Chicago and St. Louis, in the middle of the country, and known among railroad buffs as an historical hub on the major east-west rail lines. Galesburg has been going through its own transition, in its case a resurgence of its historic district.
 It also has a literary history. It is the home of Knox College, which has a respected writing program, and was the birthplace of Carl Sandburg.
 Amid pronouncements that the short story is on life support, the Night Train editors are optimistic about the future of the genre. A Nov. 13 reading held by the magazine in a Kings Park pub, the Union Square Tavern, drew successful writers from across the country as well as a crowd of locals, Ms. Henderson said. Some were hecklers, but others, she said, were new fans of the short story.
 To choose the 18 pieces in the Kings Park issue, Ms. Henderson said, the editors culled through a few thousand submissions.
 ''In all the aspects of my life, that is the one place where people are just on fire,'' she said. ''And by getting a place interested in seeing its name in lights, we're doing our best to expand the boundaries of the audience.''
 Night Train is sold on Long Island in Barnes & Noble bookstores and at the BookHampton shop in East Hampton. Information: www.nighttrainmagazine.com.

HEADLINE: With Fares Rising, So Is Riders' Dismay

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN

 BODY:
FOR Robell Yeung of Port Washington, the scheduled March fare increase of as much as 15.2 percent on the Long Island Rail Road could not come at a worse time.
 ''The economy is very bad, my husband just got laid off and he can't find a job with the same salary,'' she said as she arrived at Pennsylvania Station last Monday morning. ''It's very hard to maintain a household and manage the monthly expenses.''
 Ms. Yeung, who works as a garment importer in Manhattan, said she thought the fare increase, approved by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Dec. 16, was unfair because ''we just got hit with an increase about a year ago of 20 to 30 percent, and we shouldn't have another one in such a short time.'' 
 Gloria Luna of Melville voiced similar sentiments as she walked through Penn Station.
 ''I think it's horrible,'' said Ms. Luna, who markets cosmetics. ''And they are warning that service will still be reduced. The railroad is inefficiently organized, and they are not doing anything to make any significant changes to improve it.''
 Aboard the 7:47 a.m. from Deer Park to Penn Station, Keela A. Bacchus, an administrative assistant from Deer Park, said she was also upset about the fare increases, which will average 5 percent.
 ''You can barely make ends meet now,'' she said. ''I'm appalled. There was a big surplus. What happened to it?''
 Kathleen K. Grgin of Hauppauge, seated next to her, replied, ''They gave it away in salaries.''
 Ms. Grgin, who works for a computer software firm in the city, said she was referring to the 22 percent pay raise of $42,500 that was quietly given this year to Katherine N. Lapp, executive director of the M.T.A. It projects a net surplus of $466 million this year and has set aside $240 million as a ''rainy day'' reserve.
 Ms. Bacchus said she had been riding the railroad for almost two years and was ''sick of it'' but had no choice because driving was out of the question. 
 ''And this is the worst line,'' she said of the Ronkonkoma branch, citing an on-time performance of just 83 percent in the morning rush last month.
 Twenty minutes after Ms. Bacchus's train pulled into Jamaica, the conductor announced, ''This train is out of service.'' There was no further explanation.
 As Ms. Bacchus scurried with fellow passengers in the cold to catch another train to New York, she muttered, ''This is ridiculous.''
 James J. Dermody, president of the railroad, said that one reason for the poor performance last month on the Ronkonkoma branch was the single track between Farmingdale and Ronkonkoma.
 Mr. Dermody noted that the 2005-9 capital program calls for adding a third rail along the Main Line from Bellerose to Hicksville, building a 16-track storage yard on the Port Jefferson line east of Huntington and making major signal improvements.
 ''One of the reasons for the fare increase is because of the bonds to finance the capital program,'' Mr. Dermody said. ''Almost $700 million in interest is due in 2005, and $1.1 billion or $1.2 billion is due in 2006. The last two capital programs were financed completely by the M.T.A., so it all came from the fare box.''
 Mr. Dermody said the fare increase was projected to generate an extra $18.5 million in 2005 and more than $22 million in 2006, the first full year of the increase. It is also expected to cost the railroad 2 million of its 81 million annual riders.
 Although the average fare increase is 5 percent, riders who buy one-way off-peak tickets and off-peak 10-trip tickets will face an increase of as much as 15.2 percent more. Mr. Dermody said the M.T.A. ordered that increase to ''make us closer to Metro-North,'' of which the M.T.A. is also the parent.
 He said that off-peak tickets were now 30 percent less than peak tickets on the L.I.R.R., but 25 percent less than peak tickets on Metro-North. The increased fare beginning March 1 will reduce the off-peak discount on the L.I.R.R. to 27.5 percent.
 Gerry Bringmann, vice chairman of the Long Island Rail Road Commuters Council, said the M.T.A. cited the need to make the two lines uniform ''when it is to their advantage to do that.''
 ''One of the things that is upsetting a lot of commuters is that they had previously not talked of service cuts, only a 5 percent hit,'' he said. 
 But under the budget approved this month, the railroad is cutting more than 20 trains, including 2 peak trains on the Hempstead branch, and is closing ticket offices on weekends at 12 stations. And there will be reductions in the cleaning of stations.
 Mr. Bringmann noted also that the railroad is reducing to 5 percent from 9 percent the discount for commuters who use the Mail & Ride option with a joint MetroCard. 
 Meanwhile, the base fare for single rides on subways and local buses in New York City, which rose to $2 from $1.50 last year, remains unchanged.
 James McGovern, chairman of the commuters' council, said the 5 percent average fare increase was ''only a drop in the bucket relative to the deficits they are facing, but it enables everyone to fight it out another day.''
 Beverly L. Dolinsky, executive director of the Permanent Citizens Advisory Committee to the M.T.A., pointed out that there is an $11 billion shortfall in financing the 2005-9 capital program and a projected $1 billion operating deficit in 2006. 
 ''They can't raise fares enough or cut service enough to address the debt they are facing,'' she said.
 Meanwhile, commuters continue to express frustration.
 ''I've talked to a number of people and we might refuse to show our tickets'' in protest, said Juliet Roscigno-Filipkowski of Central Islip. ''We don't want to boycott because driving is not an option. But the railroad is not making itself affordable.''

HEADLINE: Subtraction for Schools

BYLINE: By ALAN J. SINGER. 
Alan J. Singer is a professor of secondary education at Hofstra University.

DATELINE: Hempstead 

 BODY:
BEHIND the recent headlines about inflated salaries for school superintendents on Long Island -- and behind the disappointing academic performance of some of our students -- is a fundamental flaw in the way our school districts are organized.
 Nassau and Suffolk schools are divided into a patchwork of 124 small districts, most of them racially and economically segregated. This balkanized system forces districts to compete for superintendents, a rivalry that drives up salaries. It also prevents the use of economies of scale in construction and repairs. As a result, districts spend an unnecessarily large part of their budgets on overhead rather than on instruction. Meanwhile, school property taxes continue to rise. For the current school year, homeowners in two-thirds of Nassau County's school districts face a 10 percent to 17 percent increase in their school property tax obligations, according to the county's board of assessors. 
 The solution is to replace this mini-district system with about a dozen consolidated school districts. Consolidation -- already adopted by most rural areas in America -- would save money, improve education and better prepare Long Island's youngsters to live in a racially and culturally diverse world. 
 Currently, Long Island taxpayers pay $25 million a year to our many superintendents, who together oversee the education of about 450,000 students. Indeed, the Syosset district superintendent is the highest-paid school-district official in the state, with a salary of $290,736 a year. For heading a district with just 6,600 students, she is paid more than school chiefs in Chicago, Los Angeles or New York City (where the chancellor, who oversees 1.1 million students, makes $250,000 a year). 
 Recent salary and benefit increases for school superintendents on Long Island are nearly 40 percent higher than for the rest of the state and nearly 60 percent above the national average, according to an investigation conducted by Newsday. 
 Such expenses eat up money sorely needed for instruction. According to a report released by the state education department in 2002, about 25 percent of the budgets for Nassau and Suffolk school districts were spent on non-instructional expenses. 
 What's more, the extremely decentralized structure of the system contributes to malfeasance or just careless spending. In its continuing investigation of school districts in the wake of the embezzlement case in the Roslyn district, for example, the Office of the State Comptroller recently reported results for the first two of 21 districts it will audit -- Plainedge and Baldwin. While no wrongdoing was found in either district, the comptroller reported that both lacked clear policies on spending. 
 Consolidation could also ease the current inequities in school property tax rates. In Nassau County, the lowest school property tax rate is paid by homeowners in Great Neck, one of the most affluent towns. These residents are taxed at only 37 percent of the rate paid by homeowners in Hempstead, one of the county's poorest communities. Under a consolidated plan, commercial property taxes could be pooled and homeowners' property taxes replaced by a countywide income tax.
 Consolidated school districts would also be more racially integrated. In the Brentwood, Central Islip and Wyandanch districts of Suffolk, less than 20 percent of the student population is white. In Cold Spring Harbor, Smithtown and West Islip, student populations are more than 95 percent white. 
 The demographics in Nassau County are similarly unbalanced, with students at the overwhelmingly minority schools falling the furthest behind. Only 18 percent of the county's fourth graders scored at the lowest two proficiency levels on the English Language Arts test, according to the 2002 state education department report. But that figure was 40 percent in Elmont and Uniondale and 38 percent in Hempstead. Among high school students, 58 percent of sophomores in the academically troubled Roosevelt district received less than a 65 on the Regents' global history exam, compared with 10 percent in the county overall. 
 A newly consolidated district made up of the current Nassau districts of Glen Cove, Jericho, Locust Valley, North Shore, Oyster Bay-East Norwich, Syosset and Westbury would have a more diverse student population. It would have about 22,500 students -- roughly the size of the Yonkers or Syracuse systems. Its school population would be 66 percent white, 11.7 percent black, 14.7 percent Hispanic and 7.4 percent Asian. And, based on current average compensation packages, having one superintendent instead of seven would free $1.5 million . 
 Consolidation could achieve its goals in ways that ensure fairness and minimize inconvenience. Small magnet programs could help create maximum school choice. Pairing ethnically different school districts that abut each other geographically would allow children to continue to walk to their schools.
 School-district consolidation is an educational necessity on Long Island. We owe it to our children to muster the political will to make it a reality.

HEADLINE: For Ferrer, a Tightrope to the Voters

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SLACKMAN

 BODY:
When Fernando Ferrer ran for mayor in 2001 he spoke frequently about ''the other New York'' and produced advertisements that sought to appeal to minority voters. One, a Spanish-language commercial, for instance, said that ''Fernando Ferrer is one of us.'' 
 While his campaign was accused of being racially and ethnically divisive, Mr. Ferrer insisted he was speaking to anyone who had been left behind in the economic boom that had swept through the city and that it was his opponents who were being divisive by framing issues in ethnic terms. In turn, he accused his opponent in a primary runoff, Mark Green, of using racist tactics. 
 What resulted was a primary that divided Democrats, cleared the way for a Republican, Michael R. Bloomberg, to win the mayor's race, and left hard feelings that linger to this day. Now Mr. Ferrer is facing his third run for mayor and again must navigate one of the most challenging aspects a candidate faces in a city where politics has long been defined by race and ethnicity: how to energize one's base, in Mr. Ferrer's case Hispanic voters, without turning off other constituencies.
 It is a delicate question, one that politicians and their strategists do not like to discuss publicly but one that a prominent Democrat speaking on condition of anonymity called the ''third rail reality'' of city politics. It is why pollsters seek to discern attitudes not simply among blacks and Hispanics, for example, but among Caribbeans, Puerto Ricans and Dominicans.
 ''Of course it is possible for politicians who hail from one ethnic group to appeal to their base and appeal to other groups of people,'' Mr. Ferrer said. ''As a practical matter, not only to win, but to govern, you have to achieve the widest and deepest and most diverse coalition you have to get support.''
 The last Democrat elected mayor was David N. Dinkins, who did talk about race but finessed his message to sound inclusive, referring to the city's ''gorgeous mosaic.'' Mr. Dinkins was able to build a traditional Democratic coalition, attracting minority and white voters with the promise of uniting the city after the tumultuous final years of Edward I. Koch's administration, when racial strife after the killing of a black teenager in Bensonhurst dominated the political debate.
 Ever since, Democrats have struggled to find the right formula to rebuild that coalition and avoid the pitfalls of New York's racial politics. But those pitfalls are hard to get away from, especially for candidates who carry the baggage of having run in the 2001 primary. One of the most formidable potential candidates, City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr., who is black and who did not run for mayor in 2001, said this year that he would not enter the mayor's race in part because he did not want to be caught in an ethnically and racially divisive primary.
 And while Mr. Ferrer has not yet begun his campaign, he has already had to distance himself from the remarks of a supporter who accused Mayor Bloomberg of making a racist statement.
 Explaining a reason he chose not to run, Mr. Thompson said recently: ''You have to make a determination: What do you want to be remembered for? And that is just not what I want -- to be part of the disintegration of the Democratic Party.''
 As in 2001, Mr. Ferrer is careful not to use any explicit racial or ethnic appeals, but his political advisers acknowledge that his ability to motivate minority voters is central to his bid for mayor.
 But for Mr. Ferrer, those political calculations are more complex than in 2001, when Rudolph W. Giuliani had antagonized many minority voters. Mr. Bloomberg, on the other hand, has reached out to minority voters, particularly blacks. And while it is not yet clear what level of support he will have among blacks, political observers say the lack of antagonism toward the current mayor may make it harder for Mr. Ferrer to suggest the city needs a uniter when Mr. Bloomberg has not been seen as a divider.
 At the same time, there may be two black candidates in the race. Both Councilman Charles Barron and Manhattan Borough President C. Virginia Fields have said they plan to run for mayor. In 2001, the Rev. Al Sharpton endorsed Mr. Ferrer, and while Mr. Sharpton proved to be a divisive figure among white voters, his support helped Mr. Ferrer with black voters in the primary, political observers said. Now Mr. Sharpton is endorsing Mr. Barron, and while it is unclear if Mr. Barron will actually follow through and run, it is not clear whether Mr. Sharpton would eventually help Mr. Ferrer.
 ''I think the racial dynamics are different when you have a Virginia Fields and Barron in the race,'' Mr. Sharpton said. ''It became more difficult to talk about a black-Latino coalition.''
 Mr. Ferrer's campaign has not yet begun to advertise or to aggressively promote his candidacy. But his aides acknowledge that the challenge will be to build his base -- that is, to energize Hispanics and, the Ferrer camp hopes, win over black voters, while not recreating the dynamics of 2001, when white votes generally supported Mr. Green in a primary runoff. The swing vote in the general election may well be the liberal white voters who cast their ballots for Mr. Green in 2001. The question political observers are asking is whether these people will vote for Mr. Bloomberg in 2005, or for Mr. Ferrer.
 Mr. Ferrer ''is well positioned to win the primary, especially if the candidacies of the black candidates don't really sort of catch fire,'' said John H. Mollenkopf, director of the Center for Urban Research at the City University of New York.
 ''But to the extent that the Democratic primary triggers this underlying racial cleavage, it probably hurts him because it will consolidate support of white voters behind Bloomberg,'' Dr. Mollenkopf said.
 Mr. Ferrer's aides and supporters chose an approach in 2001 that -- regardless of their intention -- was perceived by many white voters as divisive when they talked about ''the other New York.'' Mr. Ferrer said he had delivered the same message John Edwards did in his presidential campaign this year, but where Mr. Edwards was seen as talking about class, Mr. Ferrer was viewed by many as talking about race.
 These days, Mr. Ferrer says he wants to focus on 2005, not 2001. He expresses frustration and despair when asked to talk about the politics of race, choosing instead to discuss policy issues, like the state of the schools, or the mayor's plan for redeveloping the West Side. 
 ''Can I frame this differently?'' Mr. Ferrer said. ''In 2001, but certainly in 2005, I will make every conscious effort to appeal to people in this city who believe that they are being priced out of it, who want their schools to be better, who need to have access to more affordable housing to want to live on safe streets who want to see their children play in parks, or too many who need a job in order to support themselves and their families.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Fernando Ferrer, who lost a runoff to Mark Green in 2001, has begun his third campaign for mayor. (Photo by G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Time Flew By This Year (or So I Hear)

BYLINE: By NEIL GENZLINGER

 BODY:
HERE on the final weekend of 2004, many of you are no doubt thinking about the passage of time, about how this was a year in which time flew by, or crawled by, or took its inevitable toll, or whatever. For me, though, 2004 was the year that time stopped -- or, more precisely, the year that I stopped knowing what time it was. 
 See, for the last 12 months I have navigated life without benefit of a wristwatch. That's right, here in the Constantly Mobile State, the state where everyone seems always to be trying to get somewhere by a particular microsecond, I went a year without having the time available at the flick of a wrist. 
 Next to not owning a car, not owning a watch might be the nearest thing we have to sacrilege in New Jersey. Not owning a cellphone, a device that now doubles as a watch for many people, is right up there, but I don't have one of those, either. So sue me. 
 This yearlong experiment in timelessness didn't start out as an act of defiance or even curiosity. It started out as a lost wristwatch. In my unkempt house, if something as small as a watch gets lost, it stays lost. Yet after the watch disappeared I couldn't bring myself to buy another because I knew I already had a perfectly good one, somewhere. 
 For the first few weeks I was constantly looking at my naked wrist for guidance that wasn't there, and that made me annoyed that I had become a slave to a man-made device, and that made me stay watchless. Weeks became months, and now it's been 12. 
 I most noticed not having a watch when I would commute into work on New Jersey Transit, which introduced a randomness to the concept of time this year that was truly astounding. It wasn't catching the trains that was the problem. It was falling asleep on them, then waking up and not knowing if I had dozed off for 10 minutes or 10 hours. It actually added excitement to the work routine, having to wait until I reached Pennsylvania Station to find out whether I was on time, or late, or fired. 
 I am not the only person in New Jersey who has dabbled in watchlessness. There is, for instance, Kimberly Narol, a 15-year-old from Hopewell who for many summers has been going to a camp called Treetops in Lake Placid, N.Y., where the use of timekeeping devices is actively discouraged. She has taken that lifestyle home. 
 ''I haven't worn a watch in years,'' she said. Why? Because if you put a clock on yourself, you put yourself on the clock. ''It feels like your days are sort of being rushed and washed away,'' she said. 
 We spoke blissfully of a time-free New Jersey -- perhaps the Legislature could finance a turn-in-your-watches program like the ones some cities use for firearms. But in my heart I know that creating that nirvana is a job for Kimberly's generation, not mine. Because while not having a watch has obviously made her wiser, it has made me noticeably stupider. Basically, everything that happened in our state in this bizarre, befuddling year caught me by surprise, something I can attribute only to not having a watch. 
 Being watchless, I did not, for instance, realize that it was time for us to get a new governor. I did not realize that it was time to begin using elementary schools for aerial target practice. I did not realize that it was time New Jersey had an official state soil, something a legislative committee recommended last month. 
 And so I've been talking to John Hafner, who has a shop in Smithville and an Internet business to go with it (www.fotowatches.com) at which he'll sell you a watch with a photograph of your choice on the face. What photographs do people have imprinted on their watches? 
 ''Primarily it's animals and kids,'' said Mr. Hafner, whose own watch has a collage of his wife and children. I have animals and kids, but something else he said intrigued me more: about 15 percent of his customers order timepieces with pictures of people who have passed on. 
 Since my new watch will, in a fashion, commemorate a year that has now passed on, perhaps the photo I choose should be representative of 2004 or something in it that will no longer be with us. A shot of Jim McGreevey, for instance, the door hitting him on the way out. A picture of the Nets, packing for Brooklyn, or of General Motors workers in Linden, packing for the unemployment line. What time is it? Time for a calmer new year, I hope.

HEADLINE: Want to Retire Early? Well, It May Take Some Work

BYLINE: By J. ALEX TARQUINIO

 BODY:
LYDIA POSNER was not considering retirement last year when Verizon offered her a buyout package. ''I always felt like I would work forever, so this was a very emotional decision for me,'' said Mrs. Posner, who was employed as a technical writer. ''I drove my husband and children crazy for six weeks talking about it, until my kids finally said, 'Mom, you worked for 31 years, you deserve this.'''
 Mrs. Posner was 56 when she retired in 2003. She is among the thousands of employees who have decided to call it quits in recent years after being offered buyout packages, which many companies have been turning to as an alternative to involuntary layoffs during cost cutting. Many other workers are quitting their jobs years before they qualify for Social Security payments, without the incentive of a buyout.
 Workers considering early retirement should crunch the numbers first, financial planners say, to make sure that they will have enough income -- typically about 70 to 80 percent of their preretirement earnings. They should also consider how they are going to cover their health care. Some buyout offers that are geared toward encouraging early retirement will offer medical insurance until Medicare kicks in at age 65, and might also sweeten employee pensions. 
 A smart financial planner will help clients decide how much money they can safely spend, as well as how much income they are likely to generate after retirement. People often think that expenses will decline as they halt their commutes and end purchases of business attire. But they might also want to spend more on travel and entertainment. ''For different people, the lifestyle choices are obviously quite different,'' said Lewis Altfest, a financial planner in New York.
 One rule of thumb, Mr. Altfest said, is that 65-year-old retirees can withdraw 4 percent a year from their portfolios -- including after-tax investment returns and principal -- with a high probability of not outliving their assets. This model assumes an asset allocation of 75 percent equities, which is a bit more than he likes. He recommends 60 percent equities and 40 percent fixed income for a typical retiree's portfolio. 
 When clients do not have enough money saved to generate the income that they will need to supplement social security and a pension, Mr. Altfest asks if they would consider selling their homes and moving somewhere cheaper. By doing this, money that is tied up in the home can be used for investment, and daily expenses are often lower. ''Virtually any city that's not L.A. or San Francisco or Boston or New York will cost about 15 percent less,'' he said.
 Early retirement requires an even tougher decision process, said Gary Schatsky, a financial planner in New York. Not only will clients have fewer years to save for retirement, they will have more years to draw down on their assets, Mr. Schatsky said. 
 ''This is one of the biggest financial decisions you can ever make,'' Mr. Schatsky said. ''People often don't view their job as an asset, but job security, and a healthy benefits package, are extremely valuable in today's economy.''
 Of course, not everyone who retires early is leaving a plum job. Some people stop working because the nature of their job -- or their entire industry -- changes so much that they no longer take pleasure in the work. Evan Lenk was 47 when he decided four years ago that 22 years as a manufacturer's representative for ladies' handbags was enough. ''I wasn't having fun at my job anymore, and my income was diminishing, so I decided to quit the industry,'' he said.
 Mr. Lenk is not looking for full-time employment. ''I have trouble using the 'R' word, retired, so I tell people that I'm in a midlife lifestyle change,'' he said. He and his wife, Diane, who is 56, have no children. ''That's a major factor that we're able to do this,'' he said.
 Although he is years away from being able to tap his retirement accounts without tax penalties, his wife still works, and they earn income from investments they made with money raised from selling a summer cottage in the Berkshires and auctioning off hundreds of antiques that they had collected over the years.
 Mr. Lenk worked as an independent contractor and his wife manages a doctor's office; neither will receive a traditional pension. So when Mr. Lenk considered that he might stop working, he asked his financial advisor whether he could afford to do so.
 ''Early retirement is even scarier without a really good pension,'' said Lee Rosenberg, the Lenks' financial planner, who has an office in Jericho, N.Y. Mr. Rosenberg suggested that the couple diversify their portfolio to cut risk. The Lenks are also thinking of using their long-time hobby of antiquing to earn a little extra money in retirement. 
 While the success they had selling their personal antiques may bode well, a recent poll indicated that many retirees could discover that their hobbies are less lucrative than they had hoped. In the telephone survey, commissioned by UBS Financial and conducted by Gallup, 47 percent of full-time employees said that they would like to pursue a hobby as a way to make money after retirement, but only 13 percent of current retirees said that they were able to do so.
 Mr. Schatsky said he told clients who hoped to make money in that way to take all of their vacation time at once, or negotiate an unpaid leave, and put their plan into action. That way, the client can determine if a hobby is likely to pay off, while preserving the ability to step back to a full-time job.
 Even with pensions and Social Security, some retirees choose to work part time. Larry and Nancy Jankner, who both retired at 59, receive traditional defined-benefit pensions, and Mr. Jankner, who is now 64, has started receiving Social Security checks. Yet Mr. Jankner, a former reference librarian for the Brooklyn Public Library, currently works about 20 hours a week for programs at the library that provide services to older users. Mrs. Jankner, who is now 61 and retired from a 20-year career as a public school teacher, is a consultant to an early-intervention program for young children.
 THE two of them bring in a total of about $1,500 a month from their part-time jobs. Mrs. Jankner said the extra income helped them to enjoy some frills -- such as dining out or going to the theater -- without having to dip into their I.R.A.'s.
 Altogether, from pensions, Social Security and part-time work, the Jankners bring in about 80 percent of the income they earned before retirement. They earned a total of about $100,000 while they were both employed full time, putting $10,000 a year into retirement accounts. Their income from all sources now is about $72,000. They paid off the mortgage on their house in Brooklyn before Mr. Jankner retired in 1999, lowering their monthly expenses.
 The Jankners probably wouldn't have considered early retirement if it hadn't been for their pensions and retirement health care benefits. On the other hand, Mrs. Posner could take early retirement, in part, because her husband was still working. She decided to opt out of Verizon's traditional defined-benefit pension plan, instead taking the value of her pension in a lump sum and moving the money into an I.R.A.
 While traditional pension plans often outperform individually invested portfolios, there are some advantages to converting a pension into a lump sum payment, a common option in buyout packages. One benefit is that children can inherit any money that's left in an I.R.A., Mr. Altfest said. And while a carefully invested portfolio can rise with inflation, corporate pensions usually do not. ''Over 30 years, the value of the dollar is going to shrink,'' he said.

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; PAPERBACK ROW; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 733 words

BYLINE: By Ihsan Taylor

 BODY:

THE DEVIL'S PLAYGROUND: A Century of Pleasure and Profit in Times Square, by James Traub. (Random House, $14.95.) This compact cultural history of Times Square (Longacre Square before it was renamed in 1904) chronicles the district's rise as a popular entertainment hub, its decline into a porn-and-drug haven and its rebirth as a sanitized shopping center. Traub looks at the forces that have shaped today's Times Square and shows the many versions of Manhattan that have occupied the same slice of real estate -- from vaudeville and speakeasies to MTV and Toys ''R'' Us.

THE STRANGER AT THE PALAZZO D'ORO: And Other Stories, by Paul Theroux. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $14.) The title of Theroux's tense, clinical collection comes from a novella about a young American's encounter with an aging German countess whose vanity demands a young lover. Temptation and untimely attacks of sexual desire mark the three accompanying short stories.

AMERICAN MASSACRE: The Tragedy at Mountain Meadows, September 1857, by Sally Denton. (Vintage, $14.) Denton ably recounts one of the most controversial events in the history of the American West -- the ambush in southern Utah that claimed the lives of some 140 members of a California-bound wagon train -- and gathers the evidence pointing to the Mormon Church.

THE WAY THE CROW FLIES, by Ann-Marie MacDonald. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $14.95.) Centered around a Royal Canadian Air Force officer and his family, this panoramic novel presents a sidelong view of the cold war and such events as the first sputnik and the Cuban missile crisis. MacDonald ties together several narrative threads, including the story of a defecting scientist (and former Nazi) in Canada and the murder of a local child.

THE NEW BIOGRAPHICAL DICTIONARY OF FILM, by David Thomson. (Knopf, $22.95.) This latest edition of the treasured reference work, the book's third revision since it first appeared in 1975, bulges with hundreds of revelatory deflations and reverential salutes to directors, bygone starlets and cinematic heroes (from Abbott and Costello to Terry Zwigoff). Thomson, an iconoclastic film critic and biographer of David O. Selznick and Orson Welles, ''remains engaged, authoritative and occasionally visionary,'' our reviewer, Sarah Kerr, said. In NOBODY'S PERFECT: Billy Wilder, a Personal Biography (Applause Theatre & Cinema, $17.95), Charlotte Chandler draws from conversations with the director (1906-2002) and those who knew him, revealing the creative and production processes behind each of his films, including ''Sunset Boulevard,'' ''Some Like It Hot'' and ''The Apartment.''

DREAM JUNGLE, by Jessica Hagedorn. (Penguin, $14.) Set in the Ferdinand Marcos-controlled Philippines of the 1970's, Hagedorn's intricate novel shifts from year to year and between points of view. This narrative collage links a Manila millionaire's purported discovery of a Stone Age tribe on Mindanao with a filmed re-creation of the Vietnam War on the same island years later.

THE PURSUIT OF PERFECTION: The Promise and Perils of Medical Enhancement, by Sheila M. Rothman and David J. Rothman. (Vintage, $14.) The authors look back at the history of medical innovation and consider notable examples of ''treatments'' -- plastic surgery, for one -- that have blurred the line between therapy and enhancement.

DOUBLE VISION, by Pat Barker. (Picador, $14.) Barker's 10th novel describes an English winter in the lives of several interconnected characters. Kate is a sculptor whose husband, Ben, a photojournalist, was killed in post-9/11 Afghanistan. Stephen, the novel's other main character, is a recently divorced war correspondent (and a former colleague of Ben's) who's retreated to a cottage in the countryside, intending to write a book about representations of war. A sense of menace -- real and imagined -- blankets the novel; Barker ''employs classic techniques of suspense, juxtaposing the calm rhythms of rural life with shocking outbreaks of violence,'' our critic, Neil Gordon, said.

FIRST OFF THE TEE: Presidential Hackers, Duffers, and Cheaters From Taft to Bush, by Don Van Natta Jr. (PublicAffairs, $16.) Van Natta, an investigative reporter for The Times, sees unsettling affinities between presidents' golf games and their ethics, and shows how much presidential time has been spent ignoring affairs of state and chasing a little white ball around instead. Ihsan Taylor

HEADLINE: The Slog of War

BYLINE: By James J. Sheehan

 BODY:

ARMAGEDDON
The Battle for Germany, 1944-1945.
By Max Hastings.
Illustrated. 584 pp.
Alfred A. Knopf. $30.
 In early September 1944, as the war in Europe entered its sixth year, Nazi Germany seemed about to collapse. That summer the German Army had suffered more than two million casualties in a series of bitterly fought battles on the eastern front; in the west, the Allies had broken through German defenses, liberated Paris and were rushing toward the Rhine. Hitler's allies had either surrendered or were desperately trying to switch sides. No wonder most Americans believed the war would be over by Christmas.
 It is tempting to speculate about what might have happened if Germany had surrendered in the summer of 1944. Although most of the Holocaust's victims had already perished, hundreds of thousands might still have been saved: Anne Frank, who died in Bergen-Belsen in March 1945, would have survived. Much of Eastern Europe might have been spared the devastation of the war's last year. Above all, the Germans themselves would have escaped the worst consequences of the war. Of the 1.42 million tons of bombs dropped on German targets by British and American airplanes, 1.18 million were used in the last year of the war.
 But, of course, in September the war in Europe still had another eight months to go. The central question about its final phase is not, to borrow the title of Richard Overy's excellent book, ''why the Allies won,'' but rather why it took the Germans so long to lose. This is the question posed by ''Armageddon,'' Max Hastings's splendid account of the European war from the Allies' failure to capture the bridge at Arnhem in mid-September 1944 to the final extinction of German resistance in May 1945.
 It is not difficult to understand why Hitler and those closest to him did not surrender in the fall of 1944. They knew what they had done: the mass murder of Europe's Jews, the vicious occupation policies in Poland and Russia, the millions of Russian prisoners of war dead of starvation and neglect. Their only option was to hope for a miracle -- one of the new weapons that German scientists were struggling to develop, the shattering of the alliance between the Western democracies and the Soviet Union, a dramatic victory by the hard pressed German Army.
 How the Nazis were able to keep fighting is more difficult to understand. Hastings offers three explanations. First was Albert Speer's organization of the German economy, which provided enough materiel to sustain the machinery of war. Second was Heinrich Himmler's huge repression of dissent, which severely punished any indication of ''defeatism.'' And finally there was the fighting power of the German Army, which is Hastings's main subject. Sometimes outnumbered by as much as seven to one, usually without air support, German troops nevertheless fought with remarkable skill and intensity, inflicting proportionally more casualties than they suffered, forcing their enemies to pay dearly for every kilometer they eventually conquered.
 The German Army functioned despite the failing of its leaders. (By 1944 Hitler was increasingly losing touch with reality; his operational interventions invariably made bad situations worse.) Some German soldiers fought because of an unshakable faith in Hitler's leadership or a fanatical commitment to Nazism's racial ideology; others fought out of professional pride or because they were loyal to their comrades; but most of all, Germans fought because they feared both the enemy's wrath and the heavy hand of the SS and military police. Even in the war's final days, with the Allied armies just a few streets away, the regime's agents were hanging alleged deserters and shooting anyone who failed to display sufficient confidence in victory.
 In comparison to his admiration for the military qualities of the Wehrmacht, Hastings is much less enthusiastic about the leadership and fighting power of the Allies. He acknowledges Eisenhower's managerial and diplomatic skills, common sense and willingness to take responsibility, but has a low opinion of his abilities as a strategist. Montgomery was, Hastings believes, a superb organizer but an uninspired battlefield commander. Patton, the most creative and aggressive of the lot, had been disqualified from high command by his personal failings. Hastings convincingly argues that the Allied generals' most serious failure was not some individual blunder like the disastrous Arnhem campaign but rather their persistent inability to exploit Germany's military weakness. The result was a six-month stalemate in the west that prolonged the war and greatly enhanced the Soviet Union's strategic advantage in the east.
 Hastings recognizes that the generals' failure to knock Germany out of the war in late 1944 reflected the kind of armies they led as much as their own deficiencies as leaders. The British and American armies were composed of citizen soldiers, who were usually prepared to do their duty but were also eager to survive. ''These were,'' Hastings writes, ''citizens of democracies, imbued since birth with all the inhibitions and decencies of their societies.'' Such peacetime virtues are not easily transformed into military effectiveness. James Gavin, whose airborne division was among the finest units in any army, filled his diary with harsh comments about the average soldier's military quality. ''If our infantry would fight,'' he wrote in January 1945, ''this war would be over by now. . . . Everybody wants to live to a ripe old age.'' When Winston Churchill complained to Montgomery about the British Army's lack of initiative, Montgomery replied by recalling the carnage on the Western Front during World War I: ''It was you, Prime Minister, who told me that we must not suffer casualties on the scale of the Somme.''
 In contrast to the British and the Americans, Soviet generals were prodigal in their willingness to sacrifice their soldiers' lives. Between June 1944 and May 1945, the Red Army suffered more than two million casualties, the Americans some 700,000. Discipline in the Red Army was extraordinarily harsh and summary executions were common. As in the Wehrmacht, members of the Red Army were motivated by patriotism, ideological conviction and small-group loyalty, but most of all by fear -- of the enemy and of their own regime.
 As Hastings shows in harrowing detail, war in the east was significantly more brutal than in the west. Casual-ties were higher, the treatment of prisoners worse, atrocities against civilians more common. Of the 50 million people who died in the war, roughly half were citizens of the Soviet Union. As the Red Army moved into German territories, it exacted a frightful revenge. Pillage, murder and mass rape made a living hell for anyone unfortunate enough to be in the path of the Soviet advance. In a desperate attempt to escape, millions fled westward in one of the largest population movements in European history; by May 1945, 25 percent of the German population were refugees. Hastings tells the story of this suffering with great sensitivity and skill, fully aware of both its moral complexity and its human tragedy. 
 ''Armageddon'' is a sequel to Hastings's ''Overlord,'' his fine account of the Normandy landings published in 1984. Both books display his distinctive virtues as a military historian: a clear, uncluttered style, absolute mastery of the technical details of combat and the ability to combine an analysis of the strategic situation with vivid descriptions of individuals and events. ''Armageddon'' is a richer, more ambitious, more challenging and provocative book than ''Overlord.'' It gives a fuller account of the human costs of war, raises troubling moral questions and probes the social and cultural forces that sustain and limit the ways armies fight. It is a book anyone with an interest in modern warfare will want to read.
