HEADLINE: Poverty Has Grown; Services to the Poor Have Not

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN

 BODY:
The word poverty in New York City usually conjures up images of abandoned lots or drug-infested housing projects in the most blighted sections of the Bronx or Brooklyn. 
 But in fact, amid the quiet streets of well-tended single-family homes on the city's most placid island, poverty is growing twice as fast as in those boroughs. 
 On Staten Island, long seen as a fortress for the middle class, the percentage of the population that is poor jumped by 48 percent from 1990 to 2000, the date of the most recent census. That rate of increase is the second-highest in the city, just behind the 50 percent increase in Queens and far outpacing the other three boroughs. 
 With a population of 443,728, Staten Island is still better off in terms of its proportion of poor people. But it is lagging in government and charity services meant to ease the struggles of the needy. 
 For the roughly 56,000 people on the island who are poor enough to qualify for government benefits, the island has only one city office to accept applications for food stamps and welfare. It has no publicly financed shelter beds for homeless men, no offices for free lawyers for immigration issues, and no city hospital. A study by the Food Bank of New York found that Staten Island's soup kitchens and food pantries were among the least well financed and kept comparatively short hours. A national survey released last month by the Low Income Housing Coalition found that Staten Island was second only to Caddo Parish, La., in the numbers of renters who live in severely unaffordable conditions -- renters, in other words, who spend over half their income on housing and utilities.
 ''Historically, Staten Island has always had to fight for its fair share,'' said Michael E. McMahon, who was born and raised on the island and represents its north shore on the City Council. ''But it has been particularly challenging to convince my colleagues on the Council and in the administration that we need services like this. The stereotype is that we are a middle-class enclave, and it is wrong.''
 The city may have been slow to recognize poverty's rise on the island in part because but the face of the poor is different there than in other boroughs. 
 Some 45 percent of poor people in Staten Island are non-Hispanic whites, according to census numbers, more than in any other part of the city. In the Bronx, by contrast, non-Hispanic whites account for only 7 percent of those in the lowest income brackets.
 Surveys from area food pantries indicate that the poor on Staten Island are more likely to be disabled and less likely to be unemployed. Independently, the pantries also report that they are commonly being used by homeowners, rather than renters or homeless people. 
 Because the needy blend in with neighbors, they have sneaked up on a community that perceives itself as generous and capable of caring for its own without government help. 
 ''It is still very small-town around here,'' said the Rev. Terry Troia, executive director of Project Hospitality, the nonprofit group that is the most extensive provider of poverty services on the island. ''If there was someone sleeping on one of the streets I'd certainly hear about it, because in Staten Island that just isn't done.'' 
 Instead, Ms. Troia said, the homeless men have hidden themselves away in places like the abandoned barge about five feet offshore near Snug Harbor, or in tent communities deep in the woods.
 Ms. Troia said she recently took an accidental dip in the bay trying to persuade the homeless men to abandon the barge for the winter. ''But since I don't really have beds for them,'' she confessed, ''it's a hard sell.'' 
 There are many reasons for the rise of the needy on the island and the increased burden they are placing on services, but local residents repeatedly cite two factors that have long affected other areas of the city but have arrived here only of late: soaring rents and large settlements of immigrants.
 Before the 1990 census, Staten Island was a relatively homogenous community compared with the other boroughs. Now, however, it is home to significant clusters of Liberians and Albanians. During the 1990's, Mexican Indians transformed Port Richmond Avenue, a shopping thoroughfare on the north side of the island, turning blighted storefronts into fruit stands, restaurants and dress shops.
 But unlike other boroughs teeming with immigrants, Staten Island has fewer of the services these populations rely on to get on their feet. There is a shortage of lawyers, for example, to help poor people navigate destabilizing events like disputed disruptions in welfare checks, homelessness and run-ins with child welfare officials. The dearth of lawyers handling green cards and deportation hearings is particularly severe.
 ''Look, there is a nationwide shortage of legal help for immigrants,'' said Roberta Herche, vice president for planning and development at the New York Association for New Americans, a nonprofit group that provides social and legal services. ''But because of the sheer mass of immigrants in Queens and Brooklyn, service providers readily go there. Not as many people know about the Liberian refugees in Staten Island. It is not known as a borough of immigrants.''
 Food pantries in Staten Island have budgets that are, on average, a quarter of those in Manhattan, and as a result they have to ration food and are able to keep only limited evening and weekend hours. Those are often the only times when working immigrant families can come in.
 Access to food pantries is further complicated because the island is less densely populated than other areas of the city. On a recent afternoon, Bill Shook, a 52-year-old white man with a long droopy mustache, said he had traveled 45 minutes by bus to a soup kitchen in Stapleton, a mile from the ferry. 
 ''There is really nothing over near me; it's a middle-class neighborhood,'' he said. ''I come here because I like to socialize with other people in my situation and also because the food is excellent.''
 The rapidly rising housing costs that have affected the entire metropolitan region have been particularly acute for the poor on Staten Island because there are only a handful of public housing projects on the island and it has the city's smallest supply of rent-regulated private apartments. Throughout Port Richmond, a neighborhood of trim little houses that were built for single families, working people live three or four families to a house. They often cut back on food or medical care to pay the rent. 
 ''Staten Island has one of the worst matches between what renters can afford and what rents cost of anywhere,'' said Danilo Pelletiere, research director of the National Low Income Housing Coalition. The group, based in Washington, does advocacy and research; its report in November focused on rent disparities in the 400 most populous counties across the nation.
 Estela, who emigrated from Mexico four years ago and asked that her last name not be used because she is here illegally, owns a popular restaurant but shares a three-bedroom apartment with 14 people and sleeps in a room with her three sons. 
 ''It is impossible for one family to pay rent for one apartment here,'' she said.

HEADLINE: Glad Tidings for Women: The Christmas Tree Men

BYLINE: BY JENN BAIN AND MOLLY ROSE KAUFMAN

 BODY:
ONCE a year, something magical happens in New York. The metrosexuals, the unemployed artists and the unattainable are brushed aside. For five short weeks, the real men are in town. 
The Christmas Tree Men. They hail from Montreal, upstate New York and even Brooklyn. They are rugged and good-looking, and if you hurry, you might still find one packing up the remains of the holiday.
 Some women like them because they are reliable. ''He is there when I leave for work and when I get home at night,'' Sara Booth, a filmmaker, said of the blue-eyed Canadian she often saw on her way to the A train from her Washington Heights apartment. ''I don't always know where my boyfriend is, but I always know where he is.''
 Lindsey Schaeffer, a teacher who lives in the East Village, found them a pleasant break from the pressures of the usual dating scene. ''They see me in sweat pants going to the gym,'' she said, ''and they still smile at me.'' 
 They are almost too good to be true. ''Not only is he nice, burly eye candy, but I know he has a job,'' said Lisa Green, a graphic designer. For a holiday fling, you can't ask for more. 
 Approaching a Christmas Tree Man is easy. Bring an offering -- coffee or a slice of pizza will do. Remember, they are cold, hungry and would probably love to take a shower in your apartment. Here are some of our favorites:


GRAPHIC: Photos: Chris Fleischer, 32, and Mark Rivers, 21 -- 35th Street and Second Avenue -- ''Women get tired of the Wall Street type,'' Chris said. ''They like us because we are out here working with saws and living things. We're kind of rugged dudes.'' If you want to talk politics and religion all night long with these two, simply bring along a bottle of rum.
Jay Bruckner, 19, and James Patrick, 26 -- 20th Street and Second Avenue -- Jay and James are no newcomers to the dating scene. These two have gotten gifts of homemade meatloaf and mashed potatoes from young admirers. They've also been offered kisses in exchange for discounted trees. ''It's kind of like a game,'' James said. ''I know what it means when a woman asks, 'How late can you deliver this tree?'''
Above, Rafael, 27, and Emmanuel Cinta, 29 -- 110th Street and Broadway -- Rafael and Emmanuelle are brothers from Montreal with bewitching smiles. They love New York and want to see more of it. But sadly, they are not available for double dates. One of them will hold down the fort while the other goes out with you.
 Pascal Bergeron, left, 38 -- Essex and Houston Streets -- Pascal has emerald green eyes and a head full of thick, dark hair. He would like to take you to see a foreign film and have a lengthy discussion about it afterwards. His best tip? ''After a delivery, a woman once invited me for wine and cheese -- Manchego and Camembert.'' Pascal has extended his stay a week, so he might just be the New Year's Eve date you've been looking for. HEADLINE: The Risky Assumption in Social Security Change

BYLINE: By DANIEL ALTMAN

 BODY:
THE familiar disclaimer in ads for investment vehicles and money managers of all sorts is: ''Past performance is no guarantee of future returns.'' It probably sounds obvious to anyone who has ever played the markets. So why, in proposing changes to Social Security, has the White House ignored that counsel?
 When President Bush set up the Commission to Strengthen Social Security, part of its mandate was to come up with a plan that included individual portfolio accounts. The commission's mathematical models assumed that such accounts would always be split 50-50 between stocks and bonds. In addition, the commission chose to assume that stocks would offer an average annual return of 6.5 percent after adjusting for inflation, and that bonds would pay about 3 percent. 
 The assumptions about returns came mainly from historical averages. And to some experts, that seemed reasonable enough. ''I'm not sure what else one would do,'' said Robert F. Stambaugh, a professor of finance at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. ''Over long periods of decades, it seems like average returns and risk are fairly stable.''
 Others begged to differ. ''If you look back at what has happened, especially in the last 20 to 25 years, we've had two huge boosts to asset returns, both of which are now spent,'' said Edward F. Keon Jr., chief investment strategist at Prudential Equity Group.
 The boosts that Mr. Keon referred to were the Federal Reserve's successful war against inflation and an upward trend in companies' profitability. ''When profitability is high, it tends to fall, when it's low, it tends to rise,'' he said. ''Future profit growth is likely to be less than the profit growth over the last 50 years.''
 Taking a longer view, Mr. Keon said, a third factor has bolstered returns over the last century: the doubling of the average valuations of companies, as measured by price-to-earnings ratios. ''Back in 1926, the price-earnings ratio was roughly half what it is today,'' he said. ''Putting aside whether you think this change in valuation is sustainable, I don't know anyone who thinks it's going to double again.''
 Taking those factors together, Mr. Keon predicted that returns from the stock market in the next 40 to 50 years would be only about two-thirds as high as the estimates used by the commission.
 Richard Bernstein, chief quantitative strategist at Merrill Lynch, offered another reason for pessimism on both stocks and bonds. ''Our view has been that the No.1 rule of investing is that returns on capital are highest where capital is scarce,'' he wrote in an e-mail response to questions. ''Right now, courtesy of the Fed's liquidity and their encouragement of investors to take more risk, there is no asset class that is starved for capital. That's why we think asset returns, across the board, will be muted relative to current expectations for perhaps quite some time.''
 Given that some of the most senior people who earn their money predicting the stock market are so bearish, why have historical returns received so much attention?
 Part of the reason may have to do with the lack of a clear alternative, Professor Stambaugh said. ''There could be times where one might forecast stock returns to be either above or below their long-run average for the foreseeable future,'' he said. ''It's one of the areas in academic finance that's under debate. People are working on it to see if they can derive a compelling model.''
 Another explanation could be human nature. ''We know that, in general, people tend to extrapolate too much from the past,'' said Shlomo Benartzi, an associate professor of accounting at the University of California, Los Angeles, who specializes in behavioral approaches to finance. ''They invest a lot of their retirement funds in company stocks because they did well in the past.''
 That can be a lousy strategy, since stocks that have been popular among investors, giving them high market values relative to their assets, tend to pay lower returns than stocks for which the reverse holds true.
 Regardless of one's expectations about the performance of the markets, these layers of uncertainty may mean that another one of the commission's assumptions -- a portfolio holding 50 percent stocks and 50 percent bonds -- might not be appropriate.
 Bernard Dumas, a professor of banking at Insead, the French business school, argued against assuming any fixed percentage in stocks or bonds. ''The information is not available to make this sort of decision now,'' he said.
 Professor Dumas asserted that the markets were so challenging that investment decisions should be left to professional managers, whose pay should be determined by the size of the dent they made in Social Security's massive liabilities. ''We should not let individuals make that choice, they are just not equipped,'' he said. ''It's not that I'm against freedom of choice. But we must recognize that some people have expertise that others don't.'' Instead, Professor Dumas suggested allowing savers to choose only a level of risk.
 Though that view may sound discouraging, Dr. Benartzi provides support for it. For instance, he and Richard H. Thaler, an economics professor at the University of Chicago, found that people made fairly arbitrary decisions when allocating money in their 401(k) accounts. When offered a choice between a stock fund and a bond fund, many people chose a 50-50 split. Yet when a second stock fund was added, many investors put a third into each fund and increased their stock holdings rather than opting to keep a total of 50 percent in stocks.
 ''Most people who picked portfolios on their own did not do a good job,'' Dr. Benartzi said. ''Even they themselves, at the end of the day, once provided superior information, rated their portfolios inferior to the average portfolio.''
 He cited numerous other examples of common errors. People tend to put the most money into stocks when equities are likely to be closest to their peaks. And they rarely rebalance their portfolios to maintain fixed ratios between stocks and bonds, as the commission assumed.
 ''IF the stock market would do as well as it did in the last 30 years, by the time people retire, without rebalancing, they might have 90 percent in stocks,'' Dr. Benartzi said. Finally, he added, assuring people of a minimum benefit in retirement -- another part of the commission's plan -- might also lead them to take excessive risks with their portfolios.
 In any case, Dr. Benartzi said, most people would rather have someone else make their investment decisions, and from an economic perspective, that might make the most sense. ''If you have a medical problem, rather than spending seven years to learn to be a doctor, you might as well just pay a doctor,'' he said. ''If you need to figure out a portfolio allocation, then, rather then delegating it, now we're going to force you to spend all the time and learn how to do it? It doesn't seem to be a very efficient use of people's time.''

HEADLINE: Picture-House-Proud

BYLINE: By JENNIFER MEDINA

DATELINE: PLEASANTVILLE 

 BODY:
EVERY few weeks Donna Leftwich drives from her Larchmont home to meet her son, Jim, here at the movies. They often have dinner beforehand at a nearby restaurant, and sometimes there's time to browse in a couple of shops. 
 The Jacob Burns Film Center counts on people like Ms. Leftwich, 58, and her son, a 34-year-old White Plains resident. So does much of Pleasantville, in fact, because it is moviegoers who bring a lot of the bustle to the businesses along its main street. 
 When the center opened in the summer of 2001, organizers hoped they would have about 400 members by the end of the season. To their delighted shock, they had more than 10 times that number by the end of the first year. Regionwide, membership has since grown to 6,000. 
 Ms. Leftwich was among those who joined three and a half years ago. In that time she has seen a series of documentary and animation films that she knows would have been almost impossible to view anywhere else in the county. 
 ''There was a real void,'' she said, as she stood in the lobby of the center one recent evening. ''But I think it is beginning to be understood what a big audience there is out here for this type of thing.'' 
 Back then, a trip to Manhattan was just about the only choice for Westchesterites interested in nonblockbuster-type film. There were a handful of screens showing independent, foreign or simply off-the-beaten-track movies. But the prevailing wisdom was that with the city nearby and transportation available, few movie lovers would ever be tempted by a local venue. 
 The Burns's success has given the lie to that notion; in fact, the county could hold a huge potential audience for something other than Hollywood multiplex flicks. Not only are residents affluent, but many are also highly educated and have lived in New York City, where they grew accustomed to seeing independent films at theaters like the Angelika Film Center, the Film Forum or Lincoln Plaza. 
 ''People move out here when they start children and they continue to have a culture and social life in New York City,'' said Stephen Apkon, the Burns's executive director. ''But as your kids get older, you start to realize that you can't replace having that life where you actually live.'' 
 With this goal in mind, organizers in Pelham have begun their own plans for a regional film center, offering the southern part of the county what the Burns offers the north: independent films in a historically interesting local theater. 
 ''There are fabulous opportunities for programming that otherwise just won't get seen,'' said Maura O'Malley, director of Pelham Picture House Preservation, Inc., the nonprofit group organized to create the theater. ''There is enormous potential here. We're looking at who goes to the movies and how they want to spend their time.'' 
 Peekskill, too, has gotten into the act. Its Paramount Center for the Arts is beginning the second phase of a $1.7 million renovation, restoring the venue to the movie-palace grandeur it had in the 1930's. Both it and the Burns are currently screening silent movies accompanied by live music.
 As the Paramount and the Pelham Picture House project look to the Burns for inspiration in their quest to cultivate the cultivated, so the Burns looks to Manhattan. It maintains a relationship with the Film Society of Lincoln Center that savvy viewers can chart if they pay attention to city film schedules: features often come to Pleasantville just a few days or weeks after being screened on the Upper West Side.
 Since its opening, the Burns has also attracted a growing roster of stars as guests for special events, among them Meryl Streep, Clint Eastwood and Salma Hayek. The center's advisory committee lists Glenn Close, Richard Gere, Liam Neeson, Vanessa Williams and Harvey and Bob Weinstein. Many of its events are invitation-only. 
 In some ways, though, it is the little names that attract people here. 
 ''I like a lot of things that not a lot of other people like,'' explained Mr. Leftwich, who lives just a few steps away from a multiplex in White Plains. He says he regularly makes the 20-minute drive to Pleasantville to see movies that ''won't make it in the big theaters,'' and to attend discussions with directors, writers or historians. 
 And just as the film fare suits more specialized tastes, the accompanying development in Pleasantville has been atypical. There is no Gap, or Barnes & Noble or Starbucks to be found on its main street. Instead the shops that have opened near the Burns are locally owned boutiques and coffee shops. The institution's roots are also close to home: Jacob Burns, whose foundation provided the seed money, was a local lawyer and artist.
 Downtown Peekskill is also big-box-free. Not long ago, said Frances Gibbs, a former mayor who is now vice president for development on the Paramount's board of directors, there were one or two antique shops in the Peekskill area. Now there are half a dozen. 
 ''I don't think a historic town could be or should be a cookie-cutter copy of what is in the mall,'' she said. ''You can go anywhere from New England to California to find that stuff. What you find in our downtown is different.''
 The ambience of Peekskill's area downtown, which is classified as a national historic district, attracts precisely the kinds of businesses and patrons Ms. Gibbs says she had hoped to get when she was in office. These have in turn kicked off several revitalization programs tied to arts in the city. 
 ''The galleries, the restaurants staying busy, the people walking around, all of those things are interrelated,'' Ms. Gibbs said. ''A place that is considered interesting and creative is going to attract something of the same nature.'' 
 All this bodes only good things for Ms. O'Malley of the Pelham Picture House Preservation group. A handful of Pelham residents began toying with the idea of starting an independent film center just as the Burns center was starting off. The Pelham Picture House, which still shows first-run movies on its single screen, was on the verge of being sold and demolished. After some negotiating with the family that owns the building, the group signed a contract to buy it and maintain its use as a theater. 
 Officially incorporated as a nonprofit in July 2003, the group has since raised about $700,000 of the $1.8 million needed to acquire the building by the end of 2005. According to its plans, it will need to raise $9.3 million to meet the goal of opening by early 2007. 
 The architecture firm that designed the Burns's sleek modern interior has drawn up plans for the renovation in Pelham. Like the Burns, the Pelham theater would have three screens, with one larger theater designated for more popular independent films. The building would largely maintain its current look, including stucco facade and fluorescent orange cursive writing that spells out ''Pelham Picture House.'' Expansion would be effected using glass-paneled walls and open skylights. 
 Ann Sorice, president of the preservation group's board, worked a decade ago on a downtown revitalization effort in Pelham. She says that in view of the changes brought to Pleasantville by the Burns, a Pelham film center might very well strengthen any economic upswing. 
 ''This could put us on the map,'' she said. ''Pelham has been a very sleepy little town and waking it up a little bit would be a good thing.'' 
 There seems little doubt that the county can support another film center about a half-hour drive away from the Burns. Mr. Apkon says he would not view it as competition, and Ms. Sorice says its audiences will most likely come from areas like New Rochelle, Mount Vernon and the northern neighborhoods of the Bronx. 
 ''Burns made the case,'' Ms. Sorice said. ''We'll hit a similar juggernaut. We'll get people who love the concept and would love to get up there but don't because of the distance.'' 
 Meanwhile, the Paramount will continue to focus on attracting an audience from Rockland and Putnam counties, in addition to the northern reaches of Westchester. 
 Ms. Leftwich's response to news of the extra cultural offerings gives a foretaste of what each might expect from the public. 
 ''I guess I'd join both,'' she said, ''just because I want these things to be supported.'' Pointing out that the planned Pelham center would be much closer to her home, she added: ''I think eventually I'd have to decide which one was right for me. Maybe I'd do one for a year, and the other one the next year.'' 
 Despite the ever-increasing membership rolls and ticket sales at the Burns, however, as a nonprofit it is not a great economic model, Mr. Apkon said. Along with the Pelham project and the Paramount, it was formed in part to save an old theater. 
 ''We're not a commercial theater, so we know we aren't going to make money on everything we put on,'' said Jon Yanofsky, executive director of the Paramount. ''Not everything is commercially viable, but we have to show it anyway.''
 Like the theaters, the audience is mostly older. Mr. Yanofsky says most viewers at the Paramount are in their 40's or older. 
 ''This is the land of the mass movies and the malls, and so you're never going to get the teenagers to leave that for here,'' said Mr. Yanofsky, sitting on the balcony of theater, which regularly shows live dance, theater and musical performances. ''I'd like to see it to become more acceptable, more of a regular thing to do.'' 
 One way to make that happen is to alter the mix, as the Burns and the Paramount are about to do with the silent-film-and-live-music program. The audiences they seek in this instance are teenagers and their families. 
 ''We aren't trying to replace the multiplex,'' Mr. Apkon said. ''My kids and all the kids that come here are going to continue to see those films, especially considering how much marketing dollars are spent on them.'' But both he and Mr. Yanofsky talk of getting children to ''decode'' what they see and be more open to a slower pace, rather than the breakneck speed of the video games and action movies. 
 ''They have to have introductions to films that are not just explosions,'' Mr. Yanofsky said. ''It's asking a lot of somebody to appreciate a Jim Jarmusch movie with no dialogue for 10 minutes. They are used to images that come constantly and fast. It's like asking them to understand a language they've never heard spoken.'' 
 Yet if they have a chance, he insists, they will be fascinated by the independents -- animated stories, for instance, or old silent films. To that end, the Burns center offers filmmaking programs for children and has created ''visual literacy'' curriculum guides for thousands of county students. (Visual literacy is gained by learning how images and other elements are used in the media.) 
 Also, for the second year, the center is organizing a ''red carpet'' premiere to take place in late January for a group of fourth-grade students from Mount Vernon and Yonkers who have created an animated film. (Red construction paper usually does a stand-in for plush carpet.) 
 But although the high school film club at the Burns is also growing, Mr. Apkon expresses doubt that its weekend crowds will ever be packed with teenagers.
 In Pelham, Ms. Sorice says she plans to tackle the youth problem by conducting focus groups with local teenagers to find out what would attract them. 
 ''We'll see what will engage them,'' she said. ''It might be Godzilla or something more current. I think they'll still see the big blockbusters, but there is a lot more, and they can be interested in both.'' 
 Meanwhile, it seems almost inevitable that as they burgeon, Westchester's arthouses will increase its appeal in the eyes of potential newcomers. Mr. Yanofsky, who is 35, said he had moved to Peekskill from Fort Greene, Brooklyn, in part because of the Paramount and the revitalization it augured. 
 ''Its draw will be that it's a small and diverse city,'' he said. ''That's what will get more people here.''
 Dana DeVito, who teaches art at George Washington Elementary School in White Plains, said the promise of an emerging art scene helped lure her to Peekskill three years ago. She and her husband, a sculptor, own a small art gallery that they run out of a carriage house a few blocks away from the downtown area. 
 ''The Paramount is a linchpin here,'' she said. ''It brings in people who wouldn't normally come to Peekskill, and it brings them here at night and it brings them here on Sundays. The area really depends heavily on that kind of traffic.''
 ''It gives the downtown validity,'' she added. ''It's just as cutting-edge as anything happening in the city.'' 
 By the end of this weekend, the major Hollywood releases will almost certainly report national ticket sales in the hundreds of millions. 
 And on a lively street in Pleasantville, theater officials hope they will bring in the few thousand people they typically get on good weeks.

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; 12/26/04: Brian Maxwell [ b. 1953 ]; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 788 words

HEADLINE: The Power of the PowerBar

BYLINE: By Jon Gertner. 
Jon Gertner is a contributing writer for the magazine.

 BODY:
In the days before the Internet bubble, the lives of successful late-20th-century entrepreneurs often seemed to follow a pattern. In the first phase, an ambitious but financially challenged man or woman is turned away by banks, big companies and venture capitalists and told no, no and no again. Such rejections only steel his or her resolve, of course, and so lead to the second phase, in which the single-minded capitalist forges ahead alone -- borrowing, scrimping, hustling -- to create the product everyone has said will fail miserably. In the third phase, he or she enjoys a ''liquidity event'': the thriving business is bought at a huge premium, and the entrepreneur in turn cashes out.
 By the time Brian Maxwell collapsed from cardiac arrest at a Marin County, Calif., post office in the spring at 51, he had sold the PowerBar company he started in the mid-80's and was beginning to enjoy that final entrepreneurial lap. A former marathoner -- in his 20's, Maxwell was ranked third in the world -- he was using his wealth to make generous gifts to his alma mater, the University of California at Berkeley. He was also acting as an investor and mentor to several Bay Area entrepreneurs. Once an upstart, he was now an elder statesman. 
 As business legends go, Maxwell's had unlikely origins -- in fact, it began with a stomachache. While running a marathon in the early 80's, he doubled over in pain and hunger at the 21st mile. He imagined that some kind of energy bar could ease his problem -- it would have to be rich in vitamins, protein and carbohydrates, but also low in fat to be readily digestible. With the help of both a biochemist friend and a food-science student, Jennifer Biddulph, who later became his wife, Maxwell began to tinker in his Berkeley kitchen, using his blender to mix ingredients like oat bran, fructose, milk proteins and maltodextrins into large quantities of bubbling glop; after more than three years of experimentation, he came up with a palatable recipe. He then combined his life savings with some money from his father (he was turned away by several food companies) to produce 35,000 high-energy ''nutrition'' bars on his own.
 Maxwell and Biddulph traveled around California selling the product -- setting up stands at 10-kilometer races, for instance, or hawking bars out of the trunk of their 1964 Ford Falcon to anyone who seemed curious. As business grew, they improved their recipe and began compiling a mailing list of customers. (The postman who took shipments from their apartment suspected that they were dealing drugs, a friend says.) By the late 80's, what was now named the PowerBar had a full-scale production facility in Berkeley; by the mid-90's, the demand required an even bigger manufacturing plant in Idaho.
 Part of Maxwell's legacy is easy to find: it's on display at any grocery store, where PowerBar, once a lone oddity, is now the center of a crowded energy-bar marketplace estimated at more than $640 million in sales per year. Other manifestations of Maxwell's influence are less apparent. For one thing, his company showed that an entrepreneur who understands a market niche can mix dogged salesmanship and savvy promotions to introduce a new product as well as (or probably better than) a big company and a big marketing campaign. By encouraging individual athletes to support his PowerBars and promote the brand, Maxwell helped spread the idea, long before
 viral marketing became a buzzword, that successful athletes depended on a successful nutrition bar. Then, by personally courting athletic retailers from coast to coast and requesting PowerBar displays on their counters, his company capitalized on the product's credibility.
 Above all, Maxwell had the good entrepreneur's knack for creating the right product at the right time. Though convinced that the gooey bars he made would be welcomed by those in competitions -- his cyclist friends riding 100 miles in a day, for instance, or marathoners like himself -- Maxwell never anticipated that office workers would replace their afternoon chocolate or pretzel habit with PowerBars. Yet aren't we all fleece-wearing, Gatorade-drinking achievers now, whether we're triathletes or middle managers? High performance is a goal for even the ordinary.
 Sadly, Maxwell's indefatigable nature led to his demise as well as to his innovation. Told by naysayers that PowerBar as a nutritional idea wouldn't work, he went ahead anyway and proved them wrong -- so wrong, in fact, that Nestle ultimately purchased his company in 2000 for a reported $375 million. Told by doctors as a teenager that he had a congenital heart condition, he became a world-class runner anyway and proved them wrong. For a while, at least.

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; ESSAY; Pg. 23

LENGTH: 1294 words

HEADLINE: Have Yourself a Merry Little Festivus

BYLINE: By Richard B. Woodward

 BODY:
News articles about the Christmas run-up have in recent years taken a turn for the perverse. While it was once common to feel pity for those who couldn't afford to buy gifts for their children, now we are called upon to fret about the health of our local retailers, many of whom, as reporters constantly remind us, earn as much as one-quarter of their annual income during the year's home stretch. Will they meet last year's numbers? That's the anxious question hanging over the holiday season. 
 With economists saluting the consumer as the hero who enables our high standard of living, we increasingly feel it's our duty to buy things we don't need with cash we don't have. And these days, consumerism and national identity have been linked ever more closely. President Bush implied as much in a speech to Congress on Sept. 20, 2001, in which he urged our ''continued participation and confidence in the American economy'' in order to help recover from the terrorist attacks. As the journalist Allan Sloan remarked in this newspaper, the president's exhortation ''conflated patriotism with shopping. Maxing out your credit cards at the mall wasn't self-indulgence, it was a way to get back at Osama bin Laden.'' 
 Consumerism in defense of liberty is no crime in America. Indeed, one of the subtexts in The Business of Holidays (Monacelli Press, $35), the glossy collection of amusing, cynical essays edited by Maud Lavin, is that our grossly commercial approach to celebrations, sacred or profane, may be crass, but is ultimately salutary. Entwining ethnic and religious differences with the ritual of spending or making money, our motley calendar of holidays -+Groundhog Day, Presidents' Day, April Fool's Day, Mother's Day, Gay Pride Day, Labor Day, Ramadan, Thanksgiving, Hanukkah, Christmas, Kwanzaa -- is a testament to the bottomless ingenuity of capitalism. 
 For example, in one essay in the collection, Amy Tavormina Fidler writes that the $39.8 billion diet industry now concentrates its advertising on New Year's Day when many women and not a few men traditionally resolve to lose weight. This strategy is diabolically effective because so many of the post-Halloween holidays-including, as she notes, New Year's Day itself -- encourage us to stuff our faces. Within the endless cycle of gorging and purging there's room for everyone to earn a buck.
 Tourists spend an estimated $1 billion in New Orleans during the nearly two-month debauch of Mardi Gras. But perhaps no one has exploited the event more resourcefully than Joe Francis. After studying film and business at the University of Southern California, he built a soft-porn empire with his ''Girls Gone Wild'' videos. Advertised on television more than 40,000 times a year, the series sold 4.5 million copies in 2002 alone. The beauty of his scheme is that he doesn't have to pay his talent; he need only train his cameras on drunken young women glad to flash their naked breasts at Mardi Gras revelers, an American tradition whose origins remain mysterious. Of course, not everyone has applauded Francis' approach. He's awaiting trial on charges of racketeering and enticing underage girls to do grown-up things. 
 National holidays are supposed to dissolve inhibitions and fold isolated individuals into a group. Even holidays that were once declarations of minority pride or separatism have become parties with an open-door policy. Everyone is invited to overindulge on Chinese New Year and St. Patrick's Day. More avocados are sold on Cinco de Mayo than at any time of the year, directly followed by Superbowl Sunday, and only a small fraction are bought by Latinos.
 Candy and greeting card manufacturers have insinuated themselves into various holiday rites, from Valentine's Day to Easter. Jason Warriner's essay relates the story of Peeps, those tasteless dyed-marshmallow chicks produced since 1953 by the Just Born company in Pennsylvania and now an Easter staple. The cute, ubiquitous confections have also spawned Internet sites offering tips on ways to ''torture'' a Peep. Mr. Warriner's favorite seems to be ''Peeps Jousting'': stick toothpicks in a pair of Peeps; place in microwave and set timer for several minutes; whichever Peep engulfs the opponent in hot goo is the winner. (The loser presumably has to scrub out the oven.)
 Eliza Rosen describes the futile efforts by Jewish leaders over the years to dress up Hanukkah, a holiday of minor religious import, with rituals so that it might compete with the razzle-dazzle of the American Christmas. By the 50's, companies were pushing everything from special blue-and-silver wrapping paper to Hanukkah bushes to Hanukkah bush ornaments. But efforts to preserve a distinct Judaic orbit beyond the gravitational pull of Christmas can be gauged by a 1989 item from a newsletter in Suffern, N.Y. It alerts the community to follow Santa Claus in the parade to ''the Village Hall where the menorah lighting will take place.'' 
 Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday is still largely free of ancillary merchandise. Only nonprofit and education foundations may benefit from his legacy. The King family tightly controls his image and words with regular lawsuits against unlicensed profiteers, and groups like the N.A.A.C.P. have spoken out against any hint of commercialization. Yet the absence of a full-blown consumer aura to the holiday may paradoxically prevent King from assuming his rightful place in the nation's life, alongside Washington and Lincoln. After all, you aren't an American icon until your silhouette can be slapped on a newspaper ad to sell a Toyota.
 Of course, there has hardly been a time or place when vulgar worldliness didn't mingle with -- or trump -- holy matters. Chaucer appreciated the joys of consumerism. The pilgrims in his tales are on their way to the shrine of the martyred St. Thomas a Becket at Canterbury, but it quickly becomes clear that a good number are making the journey primarily to eat and drink, slip marital bonds, and swap stories with strangers. 
 Organized religion has always needed revelers. Victor Hugo's ''Notre Dame de Paris'' opens on January 6, 1482, during Three Kings Day and the Feast of Fools. Hugo imagines the scene as a wild religious carnival, with bonfires and a maypole, that is less about prayer than whoop-de-do. 
 Innkeepers are often just as necessary. In Iraq earlier this year the merchants in Najaf couldn't wait for Muqtada al-Sadr and his armed men to vacate the city. Their belligerent presence was ruining the local economy, which relies heavily on income from streams of penitents to the Shia shrines. 
 Americans may have come late to the time-honored tradition of making money on any occasion of the year, but they've certainly embraced it with gusto. In ''The Business of Holidays,'' Alyson Priestap-Beaton writes about Festivus, the holiday invented by George Costanza's father on an episode of ''Seinfeld.'' Celebrated on Dec. 23, in response to the materialism of Christmas, it allows friends to air grievances and ''demonstrate feats of strength'' by hanging in the air while holding on to a bare silver pole, the holiday's only decoration. There is nothing to buy. 
 This didn't stop Ben & Jerry's from capitalizing on the show's immense popularity in 1999 by briefly introducing an ice-cream flavor called Festivus. Festivus is still observed by fans around the country, not to mention memorialized in this book and on the ''Seinfeld'' DVD's. That a fictional, anticommercial holiday on a television show ''about nothing'' would inspire a real holiday and a real product is more than a little bizarre. America's relentless consumption and frivolity may be one reason why the world envies and hates us. But for better or worse, that's who we are. Happy Festivus!

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Paul Klebnikov [ b. 1963 ]; Pg. 41

LENGTH: 770 words

HEADLINE: Back to Russia, With Love

BYLINE: By Peter Landesman. 
Peter Landesman is a contributing writer for the magazine.

 BODY:
Paul Klebnikov was different from other foreign journalists in Russia not because of his brooding determination or his courage -- both of which he possessed in ample supply -- but because he thought of the country as a calling more than as a reporting post. Since the early 90's, he had been exposing in the pages of Forbes magazine the nexus of business, politics and gangsterism in the former Soviet Union with an almost missionary zeal. He knew that such work could be lethal: 10 Russian journalists had been murdered in contract killings since Putin came to power. But Klebnikov believed in Russian redemption. In an editorial in the first issue of Forbes Russia -- which began publishing in April, with Klebnikov as editor -- he declared that Russia had entered a more civilized stage of development. He started telling his friends and colleagues that he was sure the lawless days were over. He was even considering moving his wife and three children from New York to Moscow. But his hopefulness proved ill founded. On the night of July 9, Klebnikov, 41, was assassinated, shot four times from the window of a speeding Lada outside his Moscow office. 
 Those who were closest to Klebnikov understand that his doggedness in the face of grave risk was part of a lifelong quest to explain his personal attachment to Russia. Klebnikov spoke Russian fluently and grew up in New York, a scion of the White Russian diaspora, the czarist aristocracy and intelligentsia who fled the country ahead of the 1917 Revolution. He was raised to remember his revolutionary Decembrist ancestors, exiled in 1826 after being abandoned by their leaders. His great-grandfather, an admiral in the Imperial Navy, was murdered by mutineers during the Revolution. 
 After graduating from Berkeley, Klebnikov joined the Marines' officer training program ''to see if he was as tough as his ancestors,'' his wife, Musa, said. She remembers him describing the point-blank screams of his drill sergeants and the physical drain and that he seemed to glory in having survived it. The Marines offered Klebnikov a commission, but instead he left to pursue a Ph.D. at the London School of Economics. There he wrote his dissertation on Pyotr Stolypin, the Russian prime minister who was murdered in 1911 for his efforts to reform the country. The choice reflected his obsession with a recurrent Russian theme: how good men are often killed for their efforts.
 Klebnikov himself was convinced that a vibrant press in Russia was a necessary agent of reform and an antidote to tyranny. His passion was the chief reason Forbes opened a magazine in Moscow. ''He sensed Russia's troubled past, and he had no illusions,'' Steve Forbes, the president of Forbes, said. ''But he felt there were stirrings of a better modern Russia, and he wanted to encourage those forces. We followed him.''
 In the mid-90's, as a handful of Russians were seizing control of state assets on a scale never seen before, Klebnikov took aim at the king of the so-called oligarchs: Boris Berezovsky. First in a Forbes article and later in a book, ''Godfather of the Kremlin,'' Klebnikov exposed the way Berezovsky and the other oligarchs manipulated, bribed and murdered while consolidating a kind of power that equaled if not trumped that of Russia's president at the time, Boris Yeltsin. In May, in the second issue of Forbes Russia, Klebnikov published a list of Russia's 100 richest people. While an honor in the United States, the list in Russia suggests financial connivance and violence. His final book, ''A Conversation With the Barbarian,'' based on interviews with the suspected Chechen rebel financier Khozh-Akhmed Nukhayev, warned of Christian Europe's vulnerability to Islamic extremism. 
 But Klebnikov himself seemed not to feel threatened. ''He wasn't reckless at all,'' Musa said. ''He was fussy about safety, about his children being dressed warmly, about the door being locked at night. But he was feeling a change in the air.''
 Perhaps the greater measure of Klebnikov's importance was not the anger and sorrow felt in New York's journalistic circles on word of his death, but the grief expressed in Russia. Klebnikov had become a hero to ordinary Russians for speaking the truth in a place where the truth is elusive and dangerous at best. ''At his funeral, at the end, there was a receiving line, an open casket,'' Musa said. ''And this Russian woman came up with hands cupped in front of her and said, 'Forgive us.' She meant forgive us for killing Paul. A foreign journalist became a hero in the country he was writing about. And he went out and got killed for it.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: The morning after Klebnikov was killed on the street outside his Moscow office, the building in the rear. (Photograph by Mikhail Metzel/Associated Press.)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: WRITERS (90%); JOURNALISM (90%); PRIME MINISTERS (76%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (76%); BUSINESS EDUCATION (76%); MILITARY SCHOOLS & ACADEMIES (68%); MILITARY TRAINING (68%) News and News Media; Biographical Information

ORGANIZATION: Forbes Russia (Magazine)

HEADLINE: The Governor's Five-Casino Monte

 BODY:
This page has long felt that the state plan to allow three gambling casinos in the Catskills could mean real trouble for New York. Gov. George Pataki's latest rethinking of that idea -- five casinos in the Catskills -- certainly will not make things any better. 
 Mr. Pataki, who envisions a network of Indian-owned gambling parlors in the aging resort areas of Sullivan County, has apparently decided that the gambling business will solve a lot of problems in the short term. He and his advisers seem to be betting that the long-term headaches -- the kinds seen in Atlantic City or Las Vegas or Connecticut over the years -- will not happen on his watch. The plan is intended to bring jobs to an area that has been in an economic slump for decades. And if contracts between the state and the tribes are negotiated as advertised, there is the prospect of the state getting a cut of casino profits. 
 There are still many hurdles -- state, federal and tribal -- to clear before the first chip falls. But many are already growing understandably wary, even at the designated site for the nation's newest gambling hub. Anthony Cellini, supervisor of the Town of Thompson and a casino supporter, told The Times that people are getting nervous now that the number of casinos seems to be rising. ''Five casinos could be a problem,'' he acknowledged in a clear example of understatement. 
 For gambling advocates and developers, five casinos is a jackpot. Having a cluster of gambling resorts in one area provides what a casino developer has called a critical mass. This particular critical mass would draw 30 million visitors a year to a leafy rural area about 90 miles from New York City. That's a lot of cars, a lot of buses, a lot of newly addicted gamblers, a lot more crime and instant poverty, more families in trouble, more pawnshops.
 Beyond the question of whether the kind of development that comes with casinos would be in the long-term interest of the Catskills, there's the larger issue of whether the state should be balancing its budget with money from gambling, an enterprise that bears a host of social problems in its wake. Mr. Pataki and his successors in Albany may find that gambling fever exacts a very high price.

HEADLINE: Retro vs. Metro

 BODY:
 To the Editor:
 We were pleased to see the review of ''The Great Divide: Retro vs. Metro America'' (Nov. 28). However, we'd like to correct some misperceptions. 
 Our book argues that current politics is best understood through the lens of the Great Divide in American culture and economics. We argue that the Republicans are the dominant party of the Retro states and are very solicitous of their needs. Like it or not, Democrats must become the party of Metro America -- the interests of which are severely underrepresented in our present government. This does not mean Democrats should abandon their few strongholds in Retro states, but it does require that the party concentrate its resources in Metro states. 
 Solidifying a Metro base is no easy task. The bulk of our book illustrates in great detail the economic interests and cultural factors that led us to classify states as Metro or Retro. As for a moral code, we suggest inclusion, economic and national security, and science to counter the Republican ''values'' of God, flag and family. 
 We are not geographic determinists. We devote a quarter of the book to class analysis and call for strengthening labor unions in the United States through substantial increases in the minimum wage, legislative and administrative changes to increase the ability of workers to organize, and the enormous effort needed to unionize the professional and service sectors. 
 We do not long ''to be the political choice of new-economy winners,'' or seek to identify the Democrats with the new economy. Nor do we advise the Democrats ''to present themselves as the true party of business.'' 
 We do not let the managerial class off the hook, although our emphasis is on the Retro crony capitalist influence in the Bush administration. 
 We do not ''cast conservatism as a superstitious doctrine that undermines our international competitiveness.'' We level this charge at the radical right now running the Republican Party, and provide substantial evidence to support it.
 We are not centrists. In our last chapter we lay out a vision for the Democratic Party based on commonly held values and a progressive agenda derived from this vision. 

John Sperling
Suzanne Helburn
Samuel George
Sausalito, Calif.

HEADLINE: Finding the Savers

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 Re ''A Quick Way to Build a Nation of Savers'' (Dec. 19):
 The article refers to ''saving'' and ''investing'' as if they were the same thing. The words have different meanings. Investing assumes risk, while savings may not.
 My friend works for a large communications company. His company's 401(k) plan offers one bond fund and four stock funds from the same mutual fund company. No ''savings'' option is provided (such as C.D.'s). Also, there are administrative fees the mutual fund company charges my friend's company, which are passed on to employees' accounts, as well as, of course, the administrative costs of each individual fund. 
 All risk falls on the employees while the mutual fund company (and possibly) the company will profit regardless of the economic climate.

James Simmons
Potomac, Md., Dec. 19

HEADLINE: The Governor's Five-Casino Monte

 BODY:
This page has long felt that the state's plan to allow three gambling casinos in the Catskills could mean real trouble for New York State. Gov. George E. Pataki's latest rethinking of that idea -- five casinos in the Catskills -- certainly will not make things any better. 
 Mr. Pataki, who recently revealed his vision of a network of Indian-owned gambling parlors in the aging resort areas of the Catskill Mountains, has apparently decided that the gambling business will solve a lot of the state's thornier problems in the short term. As for the long-term problems? He and his advisers seem to be betting Mr. Pataki's legacy that those bigger headaches -- the kinds seen in Atlantic City or Las Vegas or Connecticut over the years -- will not happen on his watch. 
 The Pataki casino plan is intended to bring jobs to an area that has been in an economic slump since New Yorkers abandoned the old summer resorts for theme parks and trips abroad. 
 The governor's complicated deals with Indian tribes would also seek to wipe out ancient tribal land claims against the state. And finally, if contracts between the state and the tribes are negotiated as advertised, there is the prospect of the state getting a cut of casino profits and of winning agreements that taxes will be paid on cigarettes and other goods sold on Indian land. 
 So far, none of the five casinos has been built. There are still many hurdles -- state, federal and tribal -- to clear before the first chip falls. But many already are growing understandably wary, even in Sullivan County, the designated site for the nation's newest gambling hub.
 Anthony Cellini, supervisor of the Town of Thompson and a casino supporter, told The Times last week that people are getting nervous now that the number of casinos seems to be rising. ''Five casinos could be a problem,'' he acknowledged in a clear example of understatement. Five casinos will overwhelm Mr. Cellini and his fellow citizens -- their roads, their police, their way of life. 
 For gambling advocates and developers, five casinos is a jackpot. Having a cluster of gambling resorts in one area provides what a casino developer has called a critical mass. This particular critical mass would draw 30 million visitors a year to a leafy rural area about 90 miles from New York City. That's a lot of cars, a lot of buses, a lot of newly addicted gamblers, a lot more crime and instant poverty, more families in trouble, more pawnshops.
 Beyond the question of whether the kind of development that comes with casinos would be in the long-term interest of the Catskills, there's the larger issue of whether the state should be balancing its budget with money from gambling, an enterprise that bears a host of social problems in its wake. Mr. Pataki and his successors in Albany may find that gambling fever exacts a very high price.

HEADLINE: Next Year's Holidays? Better Reserve Now.

BYLINE: By SUSAN STELLIN

 BODY:
STUCK at home this holiday season because you tried to book a Christmas week vacation at Caneel Bay in St. John or the Stein Eriksen Lodge in Park City, Utah, last June, and got this response: ''Sorry, we were sold out back in January''?
 Join the crowd. As competition for prime holiday vacation spots becomes fiercer each year, more and more resorts and hotels, particularly those that cater to families, are finding they can fill all their vacancies nearly 12 months in advance, largely from people who return year after year. 
 ''Every guest who comes at Christmas, we ask them when they leave whether they're going to come back next year or not,'' said Eric Calderon, general manager of the Little Nell resort in Aspen, where a ski concierge will warm your boots, chill your skis and tell you which runs are groomed before you hit the slopes. About 90 percent of those guests say yes, he added. (But the resort does allow some latitude: Guests have to pay 50 percent of their room charge upon making the reservation, but the deposit doesn't become nonrefundable until 45 days before arrival.) 
 That time of year is so popular, Mr. Calderon said, that there is almost a waiting list for the waiting list. ''It takes some guests years to get in at Christmas,'' he said.
 That's because even though anyone can ask to be put on the waiting list for the coveted Christmas-through-New Year's time slot, when the resort starts filling any vacancies, it gives preference to people who have stayed at the Little Nell before, and those planning longer visits.
 At the Stein Eriksen Lodge in Deer Valley, Utah -- where about 60 percent of holiday guests are repeat customers -- even those checking out after the holidays have to put their names on a waiting list for the next year (the staff begins taking names on Dec. 25). Although the Stein Eriksen is technically fully booked by January, rooms aren't allocated until the beginning of summer, first to repeat guests, then those staying the longest or seeking the largest units, said Allie Kelly, the lodge's marketing specialist. (Suites go as high as $5,000 a night at Christmas).
 Guests must pay in full by September with little tolerance for a change in plans. ''Ninety days prior to arrival, we confirm the reservation, at which time the full amount is nonrefundable,'' Ms. Kelly said. ''Which is too bad, because occasionally we do get a cancellation and they're out $30,000,'' she added.
 But some resorts are more understanding of a last-minute wrench in a family's travel agenda. At Caneel Bay, Las Ventanas in Los Cabos, Mexico, Little Dix Bay in Virgin Gorda, British Virgin Islands, and Jumby Bay, off Antigua, (all managed by Rosewood Resorts and many of them sold out for the holidays by Jan. 1), hefty deposits are technically nonrefundable well before arrival. For instance, Little Dix Bay asks for a nonrefundable deposit of 50 percent of the total room charges by Dec. 1. 
 But Bob Boulogne, vice president of sales and marketing for Rosewood Resorts, said that policy isn't necessarily so strict if a regular guest has to cancel. ''If we did ultimately resell the room, we would probably refund the money,'' he said. (Holiday rates for the resorts vary depending on the room type, but ocean-view rooms generally range from $775 to $1,200 a night. Call Jan. 1 to add your name to the waiting list.)
 If you're just not ready to think about December 2005 a year in advance, all is not lost -- there are plenty of desirable hotels and resorts that don't sell out before the ball drops in Times Square. 
 Vivian Deuschl, a spokeswoman for the Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company, said its Caribbean and Florida properties weren't sold out for Christmas and New Year's until late October (partly because of hurricanes), and Robert Dallain, general manager of the Park Hyatt Beaver Creek, said his holiday schedule is usually locked down months in advance (call early just to be safe; the hotel gets 60 percent repeat guests for that period).
 David Roberts, regional vice president for Fairmont's Hawaii hotels, said the Fairmont Kea Lani in Maui and the Fairmont Orchid on the Big Island didn't sell out for the holidays until early fall and its hotels in the Canadian Rockies (in destinations like Banff, Whistler and Lake Louise) weren't fully booked until late October this year.
 That said, about 60 percent of the holiday guests at the Fairmont Kea Lani are repeat visitors, many of whom rebook before they shake the sand from their sarongs and pack to leave. At that point, a two-night deposit is required, which becomes nonrefundable after seven days; the full payment is due by early July. (Rates for the 2005 holiday season start at $435 a night for a one-bedroom suite.) Shana Passman, who has vacationed at the Fairmont Kea Lani during the holidays for the past 10 years, reserves two suites for the next December as she, her husband and their four children check out each year. They love the resort, and the familiarity of getting the same rooms, but that means forgoing the lure of a new beach or a different sunset.
 ''This year, the truth is, we were thinking about going someplace else -- Costa Rica -- but we didn't get around to booking it,'' Ms. Passman said. ''The nicer places were gone by May, so we decided to keep the reservation at the Kea Lani.''
 Another wrinkle is that most in-demand hotels and resorts require a 7- or 10-night minimum stay at the holidays, although there's occasionally some flexibility on those policies if you're a valued guest. That also means a less valued newcomer may be able to slip into a two-night hole in the calendar say Dec. 28 and 29, created when those on the A-list don't have back-to-back schedules.
 Other strategies to score a spot at the holidays are to build loyalty at a resort by staying there at a less peak time of the year (early December and early January are generally times when even exclusive hotels are looking for guests), or to try for the sister property of a hotel where you're a regular.
 Mr. Boulogne, of Rosewood Hotels and Resorts, said a frequent guest at the Carlyle in Manhattan would be given preference at one of Rosewood's other properties, as opposed to someone who has never stayed at any of the company's hotels. (''We have that information in our database,'' he said.) 
 Resorts usually turn to their waiting lists to fill any last-minute vacancies, but they also reach out to travel agents they deal with regularly. Working with a travel agent may also help you get a reservation earlier in the year. ''If somebody had a great travel agent who was one of our best bookers, they tend to put a little pressure on us,'' Mr. Boulogne said (although agents typically pull those strings for their best clients, and you'll pay a service fee in exchange for their time and connections).
 Of course, a downturn in the economy can create more late-season options, as Bob Young discovered when he first landed a holiday booking at Kona Village in Hawaii. ''Four years ago, my wife kept mentioning we ought to go to Kona Village,'' he said. ''She said, 'You know, the dot-com bubble has broken and a lot of people have lost money, so there could be a cancellation.'''
 Although he didn't call to make a reservation until early fall, there were three cottages available for Christmas that year (2000) on the ocean, no less. The family, now numbering nine, has gone back for the same week ever since.
 But most years, if you wait until after Thanksgiving to make your December plans, you'll probably find the pickings slim.
 ''For a four-star luxury all-inclusive resort, by the last week in November, I couldn't find a thing,'' said Maureen Taran, a New Yorker whose search for a late holiday getaway with her boyfriend was turning up only shared bathrooms and expensive plane tickets. 
 Ultimately, she threw in the towel or more precisely, put the beach towels away until next year. ''Now, we're just trying to figure out the best way to relax in the city,'' she said.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
GOUSSELAND, PIERRE

 BODY:
 GOUSSELAND--Pierre, 82, a resident of Greenwich, CT, died Monday, December 13 in Greenwich Hospital due to complications of myelodisplastic syndrome. Born on January 14, 1922 in TonnayCharente, France, Mr. 
Gousseland received the degree of Ingenieur Civil des Mines from the Ecole Nationale Superieure des Mines. He held a law degree from the Sorbonne and did graduate work at the Massachussets Institute of Technology. During WWII, he was a member of the Resistance in France. He was captured and sent to a work camp in Austria where he was interned for 14 months. In 1983, he was awarded the National Order of Merit in France and in January 1984 he was made a Chevalier of the Legion of Honor by the French government. He was Chairman and CEO of AMAX, Inc., one of the largest mining companies in the world where he spent a large part of his professional career. He served as a Director of AIG, the French American Banking Corp, IBM World Trade Europe/Middle East/ Africa Corp., Financial Group of North America, and several European companies. He was a member of the Board of Trustees of the American Austrian Foundation, a member of the Committee for Economic Development, and the Council on Foreign Relations. Presently he was a Director of Royal Gold Inc. He is survived by his wife, Mireille, two daughters, Dr. Pascale Christine Gousseland and Dominque Lahaussois, a son, Philippe and one grandson, Pierre - Alexander Low. Funeral services were private. A memorial service will be held at a future date. In his memory donations may be made to Integrative Cancer Care Research Foundation, 235 Glenville Rd., Greenwich, CT. 06831.

HEADLINE: Rockers: Take Two

BYLINE: By HUGH HART

 BODY:
AGING gracefully in public is a tricky proposition for most performers, but two 40-something rockers plan to shift gears, midcareer, by ringing in the new year with their own TV shows. On a recent afternoon in Los Angeles, the singer Vince Neil, 43, rehearsed with Motley Crue in preparation for the band's forthcoming reunion tour. He's been surgically ''refreshed'' courtesy of ''Remaking,'' a new reality-based series from VH1 that has its premiere on Saturday at 9 p.m.
 A few blocks away, the former punk-band front man Henry Rollins, 43, sat in his Hollywood Boulevard headquarters surrounded by half-empty cups of coffee and a 10,000-CD collection to talk about his new role as resident movie critic on ''Henry's Film Corner,'' shown the first Saturday of each month on the Independent Film Channel. 
 ''I've done a lot of rock 'n' roll,'' said Mr. Rollins, who joined the hard-core punk group Black Flag in 1981 and later led Rollins Band. ''But I've also written 14 books. I do 90 to 100 speaking dates all over the world every year. I have a radio show. I've acted in 20 films. I'm not really an actor, but I've learned how to hold my own. So if I can talk about films I'm enthusiastic about and directors that I'm really geeked on, then why not do it? This is not about Rock 'n' Roll Boy reinventing himself. This is: 'Fan Boy gets a show.'''
 In this Saturday's ''Corner'' -- the second of the series -- Mr. Rollins and Daryl Hannah will discuss Kevin Bacon's gritty new film,''The Woodsman.'' Ordinary people get to weigh in as well. A high school economics teacher will offer his take on the new ''William Shakespeare's Merchant of Venice'' movie and a group of boxers, all women, will critique the 2000 movie ''Girlfight.'' In the Dec. 4 premiere episode, firefighters reviewed ''Ladder 49.'' 
 Besides serving as genial host, the fiercely opinionated Mr. Rollins displays his prowess as a free-associating wordsmith in a couple of unscripted rants called ''Teeing Off'' and ''Rollins' Revenge.'' ''I'm just winging it,'' he said. ''We do four takes and whichever one gets the biggest laugh and the loudest claps from the crew behind the camera, that's the one we use.''
 Mr. Rollins downplayed his qualifications as an official, bona fide reviewer. ''I don't want to be a film critic,'' he said. ''I'm not a Siskel-Roeper kind of guy.'' He credited his informal film education to a succession of cinema-loving roommates and musicians. ''My roommate Maya had me watch 'Yawl,' this film from Turkey: mind blown. The guitar player in my band hipped me to Kurosawa. 'Here's ''Seven Samurai'' -- Shut up and watch.' I became a huge fan of Kurosawa, Fassbinder, Wim Wenders, Coppola. We ended up digesting tons of movies, which makes me no expert, but it sure makes me love a good film.''
 Mr. Rollins isn't the only rocker who has used music as a springboard to other creative ventures. Michael Stipe produces films when he's not singing with R.E.M.; the former teen idol Shaun Cassidy produces television dramas. Kinky Friedman, ex-country singer, writes crime novels. The pop rocker Greg Kihn deejays for a San Jose radio station. Charlotte Caffey, former guitarist for the Go Go's, is working on a stage musical about the porn star Linda Lovelace. The 70's folk diva Joni Mitchell paints. Puffy Combs designs clothes. Rupert Holmes survived ''The Pia Colada Song'' to write novels and plays, including the music, book and lyrics to ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood.''
 In recent months, TV has become an especially hospitable environment for moonlighting musicians. The Sugar Ray singer Mark McGrath is the co-host of the syndicated entertainment news show ''Extra''; the singer-songwriter Lisa Loeb has a cooking show with Dweezil Zappa on the Food Network; and Mr. Neil's Motley Crue bandmate Tommy Lee will attend college in Lincoln, Neb., for his own reality series on NBC next summer. 
 Mr. Neil, on the other hand, will star in his own physical transformation on Saturday. ''Remaking,'' he said, reminded him that survival in the image-conscious pop music world often hinges on a well-timed makeover. For those who hesitate, there's VH1. The network is working on future ''Remaking'' interventions for Vanilla Ice and the R&B belter Taylor Dayne. 
 ''You have to keep changing,'' Mr. Neil said. ''If you look at Motley, we looked different on every single album. 'Shout the Devil' was leather and devil costumes. Then we were the glam boys in pink and white and frills. On the next album, 'Girls, Girls, Girls,' we're bikers. So me and the other guys, we always kept changing.''
 Mr. Neil admitted he'd grown a little complacent, and chubby, in recent years. ''I was about 15 pounds more than I wanted to be. I'd watch these shows with people who are a bit overweight and I'd think, 'God, I wish something like that would happen to me, to light a fire under my butt and get me into the gym.'''
 That's precisely what happened last February, Mr. Neil recalled. ''I'm in South Beach, where everybody looks really good, sitting by the pool with a cocktail when I get this phone call from VH1 and my managers.''
 They explained the concept and Mr. Neil signed on for a 90-day transformation. As cameras rolled, he changed his hair color from blond to brown, sang his first power ballad, stopped drinking vodka, gave up junk food, lost 30 pounds and spent at least eight hours under the knife. ''They did a lot of things,'' Mr. Neil said. ''Brow lift, upper-lower eyes, partial face-lift, cheek implants, nose job, jaw line sculpturing. A lot of people think once you get that kind of surgery you turn out looking like Ethel Merman, and it's not like that. You look refreshed, like every night you've had a great night's sleep.''
 Getting plenty of shut-eye would have ranked as a fairly low priority back in the 80's, when Mr. Neil and his Motley Crue bandmates excelled in the sport of extreme partying. But Mr. Neil said he was ready to embrace the regimen advised by his team of consultants -- with one exception, when he just said no to the Life Coach. ''When I got to this leadership seminar,'' he recounted, ''they were like drill sergeants, screaming at each other, and they want you to scream back at them. I got hoarse the first night. I was still on tour at the time. I couldn't see myself screaming for the next few days, so I was like, 'I can't deal with this. I've got shows to do.'''
